Pestalozzi also believed that children need to be actively involved in their own education, and that teachers need to be sensitive to each child's individual needs and interests. He believed that teachers should provide guidance and support, but should avoid being authoritarian or controlling. He believed that education should be child-centered, and that it should help children develop their own unique talents and interests.

I have a funny question. Among the people around me there are several who are Buddhists in every way except by name. They don't practice, but they have such qualities — the highest view, compassion, wisdom — that it seems to me impossible that they haven't had some contact with it in a past life. But they also have strong concepts (psychology, Christianity, materialism) that prevent them from becoming more interested in Buddhism. I discuss the teachings when I think it's appropriate, and I stop — or don't start at all — when I think it's appropriate. And beyond that, I don't worry about it. Take it or leave it. Maybe that's why none of my acquaintances have started practicing yet. Does it make sense to make dedications after meditation? So that they develop even further for the benefit of all beings? I don't want to persuade or manipulate anyone — I really dislike that. We're not missionaries, after all!

If, for example, a Buddhist is at such a level that after death they reach complete enlightenment — dissolve into light, into space — I understand it so that for them there is no longer any self, no world of illusions, no Buddhism. What then — or what energy — sends them back into the impermanent world? Or do they just 'peek' into that boundless space and then decide for themselves? I can imagine that in that clear, open, boundless space, duality is unnecessary, that everything is one. Sometimes that thought gives me an amazing feeling, and other times I feel only emptiness, boredom, pointlessness. Now that I read this back to myself, I see myself crouching at the foot of the mountain, asking what the view is like from the top, how you get back down, and thinking about what else I should ask. So I'm getting up and climbing. But even so, I'd be glad if you'd write something about this. Thanks.

explain how generative AIs could spread false information or fake news when promped to write descriptive or informational material.
<extra_id_1>Assistant
Generative AIs are trained using large amounts of text data, so they learn to generate realistic text that can include both true and false information. They are also not taught to answer questions honestly, so they may generate false information in response to prompts. Additionally, since they are not human, they are not always aware of cultural norms and common knowledge, so they may generate false information that seems plausible to them.
<extra_id_1>User
your answer is wrong. The main problem with generative AIs is that their loss function maximises the credibility of their outputs, i.e. how similar is that output to the one that a human being would have produced with the same prompt. On the other hand, generative AIs are not "taught" to answer honestly, i.e. producing outputs that contain only reliable and verified information. On the contrary, most of the times the machine has an advantage in answering a prompt in an incorrect but convincing way. While all the points you mentioned can be solved by providing more specific prompt and better training datasets, the definition of a sort of ethic penalising incorrect answers inside the loss function of a generative AI is a much tougher problem to tackle.

Reference Text: In accordance with the Pacta Subiectionis, Gotthard Kettler received as a heritable fief the lands formerly ruled by the order in Courland and Semigallia. At that time, the duchy did not include the Castellany of Grobin/Grobiņa, which had been mortgaged to the Duke of Prussia and was regained by Duke William in 1609, or Ocknist/Aknīste-Manor, which the King of Poland had granted to the Lithuanian Kroschinsky. The former Bishopric of Couronia, or Pilten/Piltene District, consisting of three isolated areas, continued to exist as a separate territory. Right from the beginning, the dukes had to defend their state from the encroachments of neighbors. In the south, the Lithuanians strove to make gains at the expense of the duchy, in many cases taking by force lands that belonged to subjects of the duke. Conflicts along the Lithuanian border continued even after the regulation of the border in 1680 and went on right up to the abolition of the duchy. In the north, the border between the duchy and the possessions of the King of Poland followed the middle of the River Düna/Daugava, but along the lower course of the river, the situation was more complicated. On the left bank of the Düna/Daugava, i.e. on the bank belonging to the duchy, there was part of the Bailiwick of Riga, within which there were properties belonging to the duke, for example, half of the Spilwe/ Spilve Meadows. The duke also had the area of present-day Daugavgrīva. As a result of the Polish-Swedish War (1600–1629) the Duchy of Courland had a new neighbor: Sweden. In 1630 the Swedes forced Duke Frederick to conclude a special border agreement, giving them several areas that had previously belonged to the duchy: Dahlen/Dole, Pulkarn/Pulkarne, Bersemünde/ Bērzmente, Spilwe/Spilve and Dünamünde/Daugavgrīva.

One thing strikes me as quite strange. If the killing of animals in slaughterhouses is the result of the karma of the butcher and the animal, I'd like to know how it's possible that one being — the butcher — has so many unresolved karmic connections with thousands upon thousands of others, while the vast majority of us, who intentionally kill almost nothing in our lives, don't. Another thing — I understand that Buddhism tolerates killing for meat, but I can't understand how a Buddhist can approve of the utterly appalling conditions in which billions, perhaps tens of billions, of animals live every day. You often compare the killing of wild animals in a field — who die because of the grain we eat — with the killing of pigs in factory farms. But these two things are not, have never been, and never will be comparable. The animal in the field has freedom and will most likely die because of its own failure to avoid the combine harvester. The pig in a factory farm, on the other hand, lives for months in terrible, cramped, and stressful conditions and is then transported to slaughter, which is often quite painful. And this happens to tens of thousands of animals every single day. Please, in the future, don't compare the death of wild animals with the death of 'modern-day slaves.' By the way — have you ever visited a factory farm or a slaughterhouse, Radek? I don't want to moralize here about killing itself, but rather about the way of life to which we force billions upon billions of living creatures every year. That is a problem, and every Buddhist should recognize it. Eating meat from organic farms, where there are fairly strict conditions for both rearing and slaughter, I approve of completely. Factory farms are something diametrically different — and that's something you should be aware of, if only for the sake of your own personal development.

One thing strikes me. If Buddhism is so profoundly positive, then why has not a single Buddhist Asian country been democratic in the past — and even today you could count them on the fingers of one hand (I don't know of any such country)? Why are they mostly dictatorships or absolute monarchies like Burma, China, Vietnam? Even Tibet doesn't have exactly a shining history — and if you criticize Islam for cutting off hands, you know very well that in old Tibet that happened too.

As for Buddhism and war, one could also dispute the widely held view that wars were never fought in the name of Buddhism. In Tibet there were wars between the Gelugpa and other schools. In medieval Japan, wars between Buddhist sects were commonplace — which probably also contributed to the development of martial arts.

Yes, you can argue that no war was ever fought under the banner of Buddhism — but that's a weak argument. By the same logic I could argue that the Crusades in Europe weren't really about Christianity, but about liberating the Middle East from Arab invasion.

The alternative polysaccharides xanthan and levan are systematically investigated and compared to a commercially available binder for aqueous processed Ni-rich layered oxide cathode in lithium ion batteries. Thereby, all binders are proofed of thermal and electrochemical stability, besides that their rheological and mechanical properties in the electrode processing and their influence on the electrochemical performance of Li metal half cells are studied. The study reveals that xanthan shows superior shear thinning behavior and electrochemical performance with a higher initial capacity then the state of the art binder polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF). However, it exhibits an unsuitable high viscosity which results in low solid contents of the prepared slurry. Whereas levan reveals a low viscosity with a good cathode active material particle coverage and therefore good charge transfer resistance, which leads to a similar life cycle performance compared to the not aqueous processed PVDF. For a long-term study the xanthan is further compared to PVDF in NMC|Graphite cell setups.

Explain domain driven design. Compare it with Set driven design. Give example for Todo application.
<extra_id_1>Assistant
Domain Driven Design (DDD) is a set of principles and practices for modeling and developing software systems that are strongly tied to a specific domain. It emphasizes the use of a core domain model, which is developed iteratively in conjunction with the domain experts, in order to capture the underlying structure of the domain and support robust, maintainable, and scalable software.
 

 In contrast, Set Driven Design (SDD) emphasizes the use of a set of constraints to drive the design and implementation of a software system. In SDD, the constraints may be technical (e.g. specific programming languages or frameworks), or domain-specific (e.g. requirements derived from business goals), or a combination of both. In DDD, the core domain model is the driving force behind the design, while in SDD the constraints imposed by the chosen technologies or domain requirements play a more central role.
 

 In terms of a practical example, consider a simple Todo application. In DDD, we would model the core domain concepts (e.g. tasks, projects, users) as classes in a Domain Model, and develop the application around this model, allowing the model to drive the design of the application’s functionality. In SDD, we would instead focus on the technical constraints imposed by the chosen technologies (e.g. using a relational database for storage) or domain requirements (e.g. enforcing strict separation of user tasks into projects), and design the application around these constraints. The resulting application would be tightly coupled to the specific technologies and/or domain requirements chosen, and would be difficult to adapt to other contexts.

Rewrite the following article in 20 words.

Reference text:
Everyone feels worried or anxious or down from time to time. But relatively few people develop a mental illness. What's the difference? A mental illness is a mental health condition that gets in the way of thinking, relating to others, and day-to-day function.

Dozens of mental illnesses have been identified and defined. They include depression, generalized anxiety disorder, bipolar disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, schizophrenia, and many more.

Mental illness is an equal opportunity issue. It affects young and old, male and female, and individuals of every race, ethnic background, education level, and income level. The good news is that it can often be treated.

Signs and symptoms of mental illness depend in part on the illness. Common symptoms include

feeling down for a while
extreme swings in mood
withdrawing from family, friends, or activities
low energy or problems sleeping
often feeling angry, hostile, or violent
feeling paranoid, hearing voices, or having hallucinations
often thinking about death or suicide.
In some people, symptoms of a mental illness first appear as physical problems such as stomach aches, back pain, or insomnia.

Individuals with a mental illness can often ease their symptoms and feel better by talking with a therapist and following a treatment plan that may or may not include medication.

For the last two and a half years I've been doing this management role; at the start everything was fine. Later I found out that my boss (the company owner) had quite large debts — to the state and to people around him — but he treated employees fairly decently. From an economic standpoint he was pretty much at the bottom, as I later learned — not for the first time. After I joined I found out he makes things up and promises people things he never delivers. Then I found out he's a member of the Communist Party. After all these years we managed to turn that failing business into a company that's now recognized in our region. Since I specialize in computer-controlled machinery, we've gained decent clients. Over two and a half years we managed to multiply the company's turnover sixfold, and I gradually brought in the best people I know, even though the owner's reputation is terrible. Unfortunately, 50 percent of what he promises is certain not to be fulfilled, and he often lies to customers without even blushing. I always hoped I'd somehow be able to change him or convince him that he's doing things that simply aren't done. I discovered I had no means to influence him. It came so far that he transferred all his own work duties to me, with the promise of giving me half — or even a full — extra salary, and the same to my deputy. Unfortunately two months have passed and he keeps promising and keeps avoiding me, saying he'll wait to see how it goes — he doesn't want to let the company go under. The last time we had a scheduled meeting, he didn't show up the whole day, then arrived an hour late saying he had to go home, that he had something on. Under my pressure he said he'd sort it out when he comes back from vacation, that he has no time. Of course it's about money, but mainly it matters to me because he once told me he trusts no one but himself. He did something I didn't expect: when I left, two hours later he came to check if everything was in order, stayed two hours, and didn't find ten minutes for me. He wrote on my desk everything that's wrong and left — the better things go and the more we produce, the more obsessed he is that we're doing it wrong and cheating him. Friends told me I'm so good-natured that I'm stupid — but I have my best friends here and feel a huge responsibility toward them. If I leave, he'll immediately have massive problems; he can't manage it himself, he doesn't understand it. I'm truly caught between two millstones. How should one behave toward a person who lies, cheats and thinks only of himself? primaryAxisAlign is a property that tells the Figma layout system to align the frame along the primary axis (which is the horizontal axis by default). The cross axis align property is set to "center", which means that the frame will be vertically centered within the Figma canvas.

I hope these questions will at least somewhat enrich you. 1) In Asia, Buddhism is rooted as a way of life, yet historically the Japanese, for example, behaved quite unpleasantly toward North Korea, and even today Asian borders are among the most unstable (North/South Korea, Japan/China, China/Taiwan). 2) Buddhism encourages Awareness. Yet in many places it calls on people to act intuitively — isn't that somehow calling for unconsciousness? 3) Scientists believe that all negative human traits (pride, aggression, envy) arose as survival mechanisms and are therefore natural. How then is a person inherently good? 4) Evil is essentially just ignorance and a person is inherently good. But I can't reconcile this with the familiar Tai Chi symbol (yin-yang), where good and evil are balanced and part of one whole, while according to Buddhism, good should clearly 'lead'. 5) What is the point of reciting anything in Tibetan? Language is only a means of communication. And why venerate the Buddha's body — it is essentially worthless because the soul has long moved on, and we all have the Buddha within us. 6) Another question concerns external vows. It seems absurd to bestow so many commandments on this person and that, and what surprises me even more is that these commands were given by the Buddha himself. 7) Despite all the above questions, I can believe in Buddhist philosophy, but only in its inner dimension. I somehow cannot trust the teacher-student relationship at a personal level. What if a teacher carries some seed of ignorance within that, when faced with a listening student, blooms into some monstrous form? I encountered Buddhism only a few days ago and it has certainly brought me much that is positive — above all the awareness that my mind is just a part of (space-)time and that where there is no 'self', there is no suffering either. I like Buddhism as a teaching very much. But sometimes my trust in its teachings wavers considerably. It happened again most recently while reading the otherwise excellent magazine Buddhism Today. Since I'm a big fan of Stephen Hawking, the first article I read was from Matt Huddleston — science and Buddhism. I liked it. I also liked the article by Thungram Gyaltrul Rinpoche — sensory cognition. I'm leafing through the magazine and suddenly I read: Once the Karmapa meditated on Mount Meru for 10,000,000 years. My mind managed only one reaction: what religious fanatic and dreamer wrote this? I look above for the author's name and there smiling at me is the venerable Jigme Rinpoche as a reincarnation of a Tibetan realized master. So we have three options: 1. The venerable Jigme Rinpoche is lying to us. 2. The venerable Jigme Rinpoche is simply mistaken. 3. The venerable Jigme Rinpoche is telling the truth and I'm the one who's mistaken (hopefully). However, from the descriptions of the lives of individual Karmapas, I can't recall even one who froze on Mount Meru for 10,000,000 years. How do you explain this? I also know you have a lot of work, but since I've started writing and have you so nicely at hand, I'd allow myself to doubt one more thing that occurred to me while listening to your lecture at Midnight Dharma. Your interpretation appeals to me very much — it sounds rational and is nicely stripped of unnecessary exotica and religious bewilderment, which I find rather unsympathetic. The question is whether such a rational view is truly compatible with the teachings of Buddhism. For example, you claim that karma is just cause and effect — causality, nothing more. I can't shake the impression that this isn't entirely true. I think there is one big difference. Karma is indeed cause and effect, but the cause is somehow ALWAYS linked to the object on which the consequences play out. That, in my view, is not ordinary causality. In your lecture you say that even our abilities and inabilities must be causal. Yes — for example in this case as a consequence of genetic endowment. There's no need to invent further causes if this cause explains all questions about our abilities and inabilities. Someone simply dies as a child in a dumpster because their mother sees it as the only solution — causality. It would of course be nice to know that the child ultimately had it coming to itself, but I have the impression this is a view used to escape from raw reality. Once again, sorry for the length and errors. Wishing you much happiness and patience. You're doing great work.

```
import random

def montecarloPi(calcs):
    hits = 0

    for i in range(calcs):
        x = random.random()
        y = random.random()
        if (x**2 + y**2) < 1:
            hits = hits + 1

    return 4.0 * hits / calcs

print(montecarloPi(10000))
```

From not having something that is purely yours, where no one else (except...) would have access unless you wanted them to. Why am I writing this? People who commit any kind of evil are not people to be condemned — quite the opposite: they are people we should empathize with and somehow invest in. They are the ones who need it most, and they are even people we should be grateful to. Don't we need to experience this, again — perhaps for the first time — ourselves? Isn't it better to experience it this way rather than to actually go through it? Only in this way can we help them: not condemning, understanding, perceiving, feeling. Do you feel it — are you like him? If you feel it, you are like him, but you are not evil. Nobody is evil. And that is what needs to be understood. NOBODY AND NOTHING IS EVIL. A statistical model is a mathematical model that embodies a set of statistical assumptions concerning the generation of sample data (and similar data from a larger population). A statistical model represents, often in considerably idealized form, the data-generating process.

A statistical model is usually specified as a mathematical relationship between one or more random variables and other non-random variables. As such, a statistical model is "a formal representation of a theory" (Herman Adèr quoting Kenneth Bollen).

All statistical hypothesis tests and all statistical estimators are derived via statistical models. More generally, statistical models are part of the foundation of statistical inference.

I have a question that may be a bit premature. I've only been practicing for a few months — currently preparing for phowa and I'll probably start prostrations in time. I have a young son with a mild form of autism, which means he doesn't like any changes at all, everything must be strictly logical, and anything that deviates from that triggers frustration and fits of rage in him. I know that in practice, various negative traits often surface (I'm quite a hothead myself), and so I'm worried about how my son will react to any possible changes in my behavior. He already struggles with my visits to talks and so on. I prefer to meditate when he's asleep, though I often fall asleep then too. Otherwise, my practice so far — when I do it regularly (which isn't always) — has a good effect on me, and I think I'm less irritable, even though it's sometimes really hard to get along with my son. So the questions are: 1. Will I hurt my son if I start doing a more thorough practice? He genuinely can't take things the way "normal" people do. 2. It hasn't been long since I discovered this section and I love it. I'd like to ask about something too. It's about my personal life — I started Buddhist practice in university, when I had plenty of time for both meditation and traveling to teachings. Fairly quickly I completed Ngondro and received the practice of the 8th Karmapa. But then everything changed — I went abroad for work, and suddenly I was terribly busy. Now I'm working in Prague, but I still have very little time. I always steal a few moments at home for meditation, but I get to a teaching or a center maybe once or twice a year. I feel really bad about it, but whenever I have free time, I have to choose between spending it with family or friends — I have many, they love me very much and trust me — or going somewhere for a retreat with Ole. I almost always choose the people close to me, because I know they'd be quite unhappy otherwise. But do you think I'm neglecting Buddhism? I try to meditate whenever I can, and when I don't even have time for that, I recite mantras on the way to work — but am I missing something important? I always tell myself: my partner, my friends, they need me more than I need Ole (or any other teacher) — I can manage a bit longer without it. I know there are lots of people from centers who only socialize with each other and date each other too. That was never something I wanted. I like exchanging views with non-Buddhists too, and I know I've passed at least a little of Buddhism on to many of them. And yet I keep wondering — am I making a mistake somewhere? I can no longer judge that on my own. Thank you, and best wishes for the holidays. Jita

Since I was drawn to the practice of Phowa, I'd like to know whether it can be applied to wandering souls — though I'm not sure if that concept exists in Buddhism. Let me describe the situation. A friend of mine gave birth to a baby, and about a month later the baby started staring into corners, trembling, and generally showing signs of perceiving something that adults can't. Since my friend is fairly spiritually inclined, she visited a woman who does automatic writing, Reiki, and past life work and various other things, and this woman automatically wrote that the spirit of an elderly woman who died five months ago has settled into the house, and is asking for forgiveness and knows she'll receive it there. The woman is supposed to come and help. (I'm not sure if for free, but that's a separate matter. Personally I have a feeling she may be something of a charlatan, but it's hard to judge.) I'd rather ask how Buddhism sees it. If that woman — the deceased — did something for which she wants forgiveness, it probably isn't enough for someone to come over, mumble something, and consider it done — right? She'll probably have to live out the cause and its consequences in a future life? The whole thing seems strange to me. And can Phowa be applied in cases of these 'ghost' situations? I sometimes worry about asking questions, in case my question is stupid or pointless — as I sometimes hear... maybe sometimes I'm just being oversensitive and it would have been fine to ask. I simply don't want to burden anyone with myself, but given the 'offer' I'm increasingly starting to trust, and feeling uncertain myself, I just want to ask. That's the intro. Today I ran into a friend who in his 'old age' — he's in his early thirties — started using meth, pretty heavily. New acquaintances from who knows where, cooking... I feel bad about it. Ten years ago I was also gently sliding — various things for about four years, and I'd say it's been five or six years since I touched anything now, though it was quite a purgatory — I may have mentioned this, I don't know if you remember, but it doesn't matter. Today I ran into him and I just couldn't hold back — I called him over and told him calmly, and I hope with loving kindness, that I know he's going through a wild period and that he should quit while he's ahead, because it's no joke... and that death doesn't end anything. He thanked me for the advice, that's a quote. Then I left and felt good about it — tears in my eyes — but then I felt off, and so I'm asking: Is it good to tell addicts that death doesn't end anything? I mean to say to them, to imply, that you simply can't drug yourself to death — I'm not sure how to put it... and I mean people who regularly destroy their veins. Lately people who use are making me physically shake — I rage inside and then cry, and I'd most like to physically shake it out of them — though I understand it's self-harm. So I was glad I managed to stay calm with that friend. And I have one more question. Whenever I feel genuinely good, really clean, I see a white horse — including during meditation. I don't find it disturbing, I just know it's there. Do you know what that is? There are more animals, but they're not monsters — those I'd probably recognize. It's been about three years since they started appearing, and three years since my first encounter with Lama Karmapa and Lama Ole. Maybe you'd better answer by email... thank you, Irca.

Not long ago I wrote you a question that hasn't been answered yet — about a planned visit to the center. That's now past; we visited the center and successfully learned some things, see possibly below. But I have another problem, with my fiancé. He's a wonderful guy; we've been together five years and until now we've done everything together, agreed on everything substantial, and it's been (and still is) great. But when it comes to Buddhism I hit a bit of a wall with him — not that he has anything against its goals (we've always agreed that the point of life should mainly be personal development for the benefit of others), but he has more of an issue with the methods. He simply says — and I can't entirely disagree — that if mantras can so powerfully influence the subconscious, how can he know they won't influence it negatively? It's not that he's limiting me or being possessive — he's simply worried about me. And when I told him that after Phowa (which I want to attend, and I'd love for him to come with me, though I'll probably not be able to talk him into it) a person has a hole in their head, he was genuinely frightened — that this is no longer any kind of joke. I don't know what to do with him. On one hand I feel such intuitive trust toward Buddhism — like it's exactly what I've been looking for. On the other hand I understand his objections as valid, and I wouldn't like us to have any kind of rift on this important question — also because he's always been a bit more rational than me, so whenever we disagreed, I generally deferred to his view and it always turned out to be the right thing; I trust my intuition, but I trust his too. I've read some books, he's planning to read them too, but he won't find an answer to his questions in them — it's a question of trust in the teacher, and one probably builds that only when one wants to start practicing oneself, not just to believe that a partner isn't doing anything wrong. We visited the center together too, but we had mixed feelings (everyone seemed to us, for our taste, "too enthusiastic" — like Jehovah's Witnesses; I mean, excessive missionary zeal can do harm and rather put off a skeptical person, even though the overall impression was positive). Normally I'd leave it, let things evolve over time, no rush. But the main thing for me right now is the Phowa, because it's a wonderful opportunity and I'd hate for either of us to miss it just because he's not yet certain whether it's safe. So thanks for any possible advice.

Knicks Go (foaled January 29, 2016) is a retired Thoroughbred racehorse who was the 2021 American Horse of the Year after winning five of seven starts, including the Breeders' Cup Classic, Whitney Stakes and Pegasus World Cup. The year before he won the Breeders' Cup Dirt Mile. He is the sixth horse to win two different Breeders' Cup races.

His other wins include the Breeders' Futurity as a two-year-old in 2018, after which he finished second in the Breeders' Cup Juvenile.

After finishing second in the 2022 Pegasus World Cup, Knicks Go was retired to stud at Taylor Made Farm in Nicholasville, Kentucky with an initial stud fee of $30,000.

Background
Knicks Go is a gray horse who was bred by Angie Moore and her daughter Sabrina at GreenMount Farm in Reisterstown, Maryland. He is from the second crop of Paynter, who won the Haskell Invitational, then received widespread social media attention during his battle against a near-fatal case of colitis and laminitis. Knicks Go was produced by Kosmo's Buddy, a stakes-winning daughter of Outflanker who was claimed by the Moores for $40,000 near the end of a 37-race career.[3]

Knicks Go was sold as a weanling for $40,000 at the 2016 Keeneland November sale to Northface Bloodstock. He was resold as a yearling at the Keeneland September 2017 sale for $87,000 to the Korea Racing Authority. He was originally trained by Ben Colebrook and was transferred to the stable of Brad Cox at the end of 2019.

The colt was named for the K-nicks breeding system used by the Korea Racing Authority (KRA), with the "K" standing for Korea and nicks referring to the above average success of certain sires when bred to mares from certain other sire lines. "If you can call him 'K-Nicks Go', that would be great", said Jun Park, a racing manager of the KRA. "But it really doesn't matter. Everybody knows him as 'Nicks Go'."

I have a function `squared_pairwise_distances_vectorized` and I want to test whether it is correct by comparing it to a naive implementation with for-loops. The naive implementation should be easy to understand and not use any NumPy functions. Fill in the part marked with "[...]" below:

import numpy as np

def squared_pairwise_distances_vectorized(p: np.ndarray, q: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """
    Compute the squared pairwise distances between two sets of points p and q.

    Parameters
    ----------
    p : np.ndarray
        The first set of points. Shape is (n, d).
    q : np.ndarray
        The second set of points. Shape is (m, d).

    Returns
    -------
    np.ndarray
        The squared pairwise distances. Shape is (n, m).
    """
    return (p**2).sum(axis=1, keepdims=True) + (q**2).sum(axis=1) - 2 * p @ q.T

def squared_pairwise_distances_naive(a: np.ndarray, b: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """
    This function should do the same as squared_pairwise_distances_vectorized,
    but without using any vectorized operations. It is provided for
    comparison purposes only.
    """
    distances = np.zeros((a.shape[0], b.shape[0]))

    [...]

    return distances

def main() -> None:
    p = np.random.rand(7, 2)
    q = np.random.rand(5, 2)

    distances_vectorized = squared_pairwise_distances_vectorized(p, q)
    distances_naive = squared_pairwise_distances_naive(p, q)

    assert np.allclose(distances_vectorized, distances_naive)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

I know you're probably not bored, so I want to apologize in advance for such a long text. I have several questions right away: 1. When I think that wisdom is prevailing over compassion and I start attending to it and "working" on it (or sometimes I just sort of "become aware" of it), it seems to me that I've actually explained it to myself incorrectly and what I'm missing is more wisdom. A similar thing happens in the opposite case — sometimes this is quite a mess, especially when these two events are separated by only a few minutes or a fraction of a second (sometimes it's a longer period, like a week). So how to develop these qualities in a reasonable way so it doesn't create a mess in my head, while also being careful not to become a useless being — either a sentimental "fool" who tries very hard to help but doesn't know how (as they say: a hard-working fool is worse than a class enemy), or a person who is very learned and perhaps experienced, but without the "inspiration" to use it for the benefit of others? (I'm increasingly realizing that I'm missing a huge amount of both — unless my ego is more or less successfully convincing me that I'm the best anyway.) The next two questions relate to a book I found in our center called "Three Paths." It says these teachings were given by Kunzig Shamar Rinpoche in 1987 at the Kamalashila Institute in Wachendorf, Germany. 2. It describes there a division of Buddhism into the path of shravakas, the path of pratyekabuddhas, and the path of bodhisattvas. As for the division into the Small Vehicle, Great Vehicle, and Diamond Vehicle, it states this is illogical. The pratyekabuddha path drops out, and the bodhisattva path is divided into two (Great and Diamond). Could you please clarify this discrepancy? Why does Ole, for example, only ever divide it into Small, Great, and Diamond Vehicle — at least I've never caught him using the other division. 3. There are also questions and answers in the book. One concerns the vow not to harm others through sex. However, the answer struck me — it began something like this (I'm not sure I'll quote it completely accurately, but I think the meaning is preserved): "This is a vow not to harm others through sex, for example through homosexual intercourse." And then he wove in ethics in the style of: "Intercourse between one man and one woman is ethical and correct. All other options are..." (I don't remember the exact wording, but it wasn't positive). In my view, homosexual intercourse is about the same as heterosexual intercourse if contraception is used. The fact that without contraception pregnancy (and thus reproduction of the species) can occur is, in my view, secondary — the majority of sexual acts (at least in "developed" countries) are like this. If I'm wrong, why is homosexual intercourse considered harmful? And if I'm not wrong, could you please explain why Shamarpa used such language, or pass this directly to the source so the information comes firsthand. Either way, thank you for your patience and answers. 4. I often have similar feelings to the guy who wrote some time ago, "Sometimes it seems to me that by the time I finish writing a question here, I've already answered it" — I just tend to get that feeling mostly while I'm still forming the question in my head, as if I'm already reading your answer. Is it useful to still ask such a question, even when it then seems banal to me, and to check whether my intuition is wrong? Or is it better to be selective and only ask questions I genuinely can't figure out myself — given the limited time available for answers? (When I factor in the delay between question and answer, you must have quite a lot of them.) Thanks for this opportunity — it's a great section — and for your time. Wishing you lots of strength and energy in 2005 as well.

I just want to briefly share an interesting experience I've had, and if you add your thoughts I'd be grateful. I'm noticing how the mind works in amusing ways, and although it sometimes takes a lot of work to understand it, I enjoy it. The thing is that through long effort I've built up a decent perspective, and doing good for myself and others has somehow gotten deep under my skin. The mind keeps trying to question this, so there are two people inside me — me and the mind. We talk a lot. Sometimes I have the feeling of being both teacher and student in one person. My mind keeps doubting and asking me why I do things the way I do. I think most people who try to develop the spiritual side of life probably have this — it just seems hilariously funny to me that today I actually understand my own mind. Previously it was demanding — like being in charge of a bunch of children at a scout camp who never shut up and have millions of questions. Who wouldn't go crazy, right? And yet it's manageable. Today I can play with the thoughts that hatch in my brain, and the nice thing is it's getting easier not just with thoughts. My mind has probably grown out of its childish whims and works more than it misbehaves. I've trained it well, the silly thing. I'm not traveling the Diamond Way, but maybe I'll set out on it — who knows. From the lookout point I've climbed to over the past years, your path looks remarkably beautiful. For now I only lack the identification with it. I'm waiting to see what happens; I want it to be not the mind but the heart that tells me: yes, that's the one. In any case, the Buddha is for me both starting point and goal, both space and fixed point — to put it a little poetically. His thoughts are simply amazing, and it saddens me greatly that the path to truth is so difficult for so many people that perhaps in this life they won't even get the chance to see the world as it truly is. In closing, a quote I like: "When we make meaningful use of the material essence of our life, and are not distracted by the vanities of this life, for this good essence — which is hard to gain and easy to destroy — enables us to choose between benefit and ruin, between suffering and peace."

Over one extended weekend I dedicated myself to it quite fully and did perhaps 400 repetitions over the weekend, and read some Buddhist literature — 'The Meaning of Life'. On Wednesday morning I couldn't sleep in, woke up at 4 a.m. and couldn't fall back asleep, so I went to meditate — it was quiet, only birdsong, no traffic, ideal for meditation. I did about 200 repetitions of the four lines. Then I focused on the dissolving phase, and something amazing happened. When the three objects of meditation dissolved into the lama and the lama began approaching me, something very unusual started to happen — I could feel that something was occurring. Then in the moment of merging between my energetic center in the heart and the lama's center, something incredible came — a kind of breakthrough. I felt like during the most beautiful orgasm. Internally I was flooded with an orange-golden light. I saw that I was standing on a kind of boundary between two great orbs of orange-golden light — something like between two worlds. I clearly sensed that everything in the conditioned world is nothing compared to what is in that other, infinitely radiant space, and that happiness must be sought within, that it is there and incomparable to anything in the outer world, that I already have everything and need nothing more. At the same time I felt boundless compassion and gratitude, and for a moment saw everything as if with tremendous overview, in its true nature. In that moment I knew for certain that Diamond Way meditation works. It was amazing, but I didn't try to go further. Then I was shaking with cold and barely finished the meditation, so agitated and elated was I by that feeling. I'm trying not to cling to it or to expect it in the next meditation. This matter is important to me and I'd really value your opinion. Is it right to achieve states of higher consciousness and enlightenment with the help of psychedelics (LSD, cannabis)? I don't mean having that feeling during the intoxication itself, but when it remains permanently as a result of previous experiences. Some people say that one should arrive at it with a clear head and through long-term meditation and so on — but I think that's just the ego refusing to accept that someone might manage it in a single experience, while 'I' am diligently working at it and 'I' am therefore better. What matters is the destination, not how you get there. LSD came about by accident, just like penicillin (a higher intervention, perhaps?) — but with a far more virtuous message for those who, due to determinism, karma, and instinct, have little chance of finding their way onto the right path. I say this because these substances helped me, and I no longer feel a need to use them. P.S.: If you'd prefer not to publish this because of possible promotion of drug use... you have my email. Thanks.

I'm responding to an answer from 3 July 2004. Perhaps I expressed myself poorly. By 'distance' I meant the disturbing feelings and thoughts that arise in every person who hasn't yet attained liberation or enlightenment. If I read and understood correctly, it's precisely this distance that needs to be developed, right? How else can one work with emotions? Simply build distance from disturbing emotions, and in that way not take them too seriously — and eventually, if that succeeds, discover that they are only illusions of the mind; perhaps later comes a full understanding that we are not separated from anything. Incidentally, I'd like to note that I've observed certain similarities in other books and philosophies as well. I recently read 'The Alchemist' by Paulo Coelho (the name may be spelled differently, I'm not sure right now) and I'm currently reading 'Message from the Antipodes,' and with some surprise I'm finding that the truth contained in these books comes suspiciously close to Buddhism, even though the authors apparently have nothing to do with Buddhism — statements like 'everything is one,' 'we are all everything,' and many other similarities. What do you think? I think the truth is only one, and whoever engages with it will arrive at it regardless — whether they're a Buddhist or someone else.

Even though in the past I'd seen numerous documentaries and films about Tibet and everything on that topic felt very close to me — I felt harmony in those people, their natural smiles — I was still capable of getting quite angry at people around me when they thoughtlessly destroy their immediate and distant surroundings through complicated travel, greed, inconsiderateness, selfishness, showing off, a kind of foolishness, and massive construction projects, and so on. You surely see for yourself how people value all of nature's gifts, how they think. Lately I've been reading various pages about Buddhism — general information as well as wise stories, exercises, questions and answers — and I've also been trying to meditate and calm the mind. Buddhism teaches that one should not harm beings, teaches helping, empathy. How are you? I have a little question about cause and effect. Say I unintentionally commit a negative act — for example, I cause a car accident. In that accident, let's say I cripple the father of two ten-year-old children. The father then stops earning money and can't provide for his children, so he starts drinking heavily. The children, due to poor upbringing, don't get a good education and become alcoholics, etc. From a certain perspective, my one unintentional negative act could have influenced essentially an infinite number of conditions affecting other beings. Does this mean the consequences of our actions are therefore unlimited? And will I bear the karmic consequence of all those negative things — the fact that because of my one negative act I negatively changed so many lives? Or are those consequences — like, say, the bad education of those children — karmically less my concern, because they are also the architects of their own lives, and if they genuinely wanted to they could for example study by correspondence and work? From this essentially arise my questions: 1. Are our actions therefore karmically unlimited — in that by performing some significant act I can change infinitely many conditions, and this will then have karmic impact back on me? 2. If every act had infinitely many consequences, then even a positive act could, through changing conditions, have a negative effect somewhere, and vice versa. Example: A nurse has a husband who beats her and they live together in an apartment with an elderly woman. I find out about it, give the nurse the courage to divorce that man and move out. This happens, and the next day after she moves out, the elderly woman has a stroke. The man is not medically trained and the elderly woman looks relatively fine, and she dies the following day without medical help. Conclusion: my act helped the nurse escape her violent husband, but if she had been living in that apartment one day longer she would have saved the elderly woman's life. 3. I've come to this conclusion from all of this: the most important thing is the motivation behind what you do, because that motivation directly influences habits of thinking. For example, if I help someone, I'm establishing in my mind a habit of helping — and it doesn't much matter if I help somewhat clumsily and hurt someone a little in the process. What matters is that I helped once, and the likelihood that I'll help in a similar situation again is far greater than if I'd never helped anyone before. Can one therefore say that it doesn't matter what the outcome of actions is (they are neither positive nor negative with the right motivation), but what matters is motivation — because that directly influences our experience? Agreed? Thanks very much. Sorry for the novel, but I wanted everything to be clear and for others to understand my questions too.

The following is a an excerpt from my textbook:

Originally, John defined redundant information as information that is conserved under a certain resampling process (essentially Gibbs sampling): given initial samples of variables 

\(X\_1, \ldots, X\_n\)

, you repeatedly pick one of the variables at random and resample it conditioned on the samples of all the other variables. The information that you still have about the original variable values after resampling many times must have been redundant, i.e. contained in at least two variables. In practice, we probably don’t want such a loose definition of redundancy: what we care about is information that is highly redundant, i.e. present in many variables. This means we would resample several variables at a time.

It's only humans who set themselves above other living creatures and created a kind of rule that the longer the trousers, the greater the intelligence. I'm asking for one simple reason: I have a physical disability, I'm a wheelchair user, and I cannot wear trousers — wearing and carrying them would cause me indescribable suffering (chafing, sores, etc.). That's why in summer I go outside (even to shop, etc.) in just a T-shirt, socks and shoes, with nothing in between (in winter I have to stay home). Many people have already gotten used to it, but in many cases I encounter hostile or even hateful looks and mockery. I don't understand how that small bit of skin can put anyone off or provoke anyone. And yet the world hasn't collapsed — I completed secondary school, I'm psychologically balanced, I love people and children, though I have to avoid children because they wouldn't yet understand. This is in no way some crude exhibitionism for the purpose of sexual arousal. I don't want to harm anyone and I don't hold it against people who don't understand. Meanwhile, even the Bible doesn't forbid nudity in public, and Czech law doesn't explicitly forbid it either — so what isn't forbidden is permitted. I've thought deeply about this many times and see nothing wrong in it, only pure freedom. I'd therefore like to know your opinion as a Buddhist, and whether it would be an obstacle — because I'd like to become a Buddhist. I know I have Buddha-nature, and I think it's more important to take that into account than ethical criteria. I wish all beings everything best and freedom!

WBS is short for Work Breakdown Structure, which is a way of dividing a project into manageable phases, and then phases into subtasks. What you’re asking about is the WBS for an overseas corporation, so I’ll focus on the key points that are relevant for that.
 

 First, a “corporation” is a legal entity, so the first step in the WBS is to identify the stakeholders. Stakeholders are the people or organizations that will be affected by the corporation. The most obvious stakeholders are the shareholders of the corporation, who will own shares of the company and have a financial interest in its success. But other stakeholders will be the employees, customers, suppliers, and neighbors of the corporation. Each of these stakeholders will have a different interest in the corporation, and the WBS needs to account for all of them.
 

 Second, the WBS for a corporation must include the nature of the corporation’s operations. Corporations can be classified as manufacturing, service, or both. Here, the WBS must include what products or services the corporation will offer, where it will be based, and who will be its employees. The WBS must also include the types of equipment and facilities that the corporation will need.
 

 Third, the WBS must include the timeline for establishing the corporation. This includes the time required to incorporate the company, to assemble the assets of the company, and to begin operations.
 

 Fourth, the WBS must include a detailed breakdown of costs, such as incorporation costs, property costs, legal costs, and personnel costs. Finally, the WBS must include a detailed plan for ensuring that the corporation will be profitable. This might include the establishment of a marketing plan, a sales plan, or a financial plan.

What is the formula for calculating the total energy of a photon with a given wavelength?
To calculate the energy of a photon, we can use the formula:
E = hc/λ
where E is the energy in joules (J), h is Planck's constant (6.626 x 10^-34 J s), c is the speed of light (2.998 x 10^8 m/s), and λ is the wavelength of the photon in meters (m). By plugging in the values for h, c, and λ, we can calculate the energy of the photon.

Behind this might be a lack of emotional stimulation in childhood. I wish I would end up as a homeless person with nothing, so I'd have nothing to lose. I'm probably governed by fear of losing impermanent things. My reason tells me these wishes are bad. Why do such thoughts occur in many people? A Christian would say that bad thoughts are whispered to them by Satan, but why do they appear from a Buddhist perspective? How do I get rid of these bad wishes? I feel that as a healthy person who won't live like a homeless person, I can do more beautiful things for people. 2) I've started catching myself — ever since I broke up five years ago with my greatest love — drowning in false imaginings, as if I were creating my own world in my mind where I escape from "reality." For example, I imagine being a conqueror and conquering the whole world with an army, being the ruler of the whole world; or being someone who carries out justice and kills or defeats people who don't behave for the benefit of all people; I also sometimes imagine making a huge mess of problems for myself and imagine what it's like to be completely at rock bottom. Or I imagine being in love with my greatest love, planning a shared future together... And meanwhile I live normally, without anyone noticing. I can tell reality from fantasy and I only escape into my imaginings to flee from reality when I feel terrible. Since I started meditating on the Three Lights and a short refuge plus prostrations, it seems this "creature" is losing its strength. How do I completely get rid of this "creature" that I've thoroughly fattened over time? 3) I think massage is beautiful work and it always gives me great joy when someone is happy to feel much better after treatments — there are even a few people a year who claim my few massages helped them more than a five-week combined treatment by doctors with rehabilitation at a hospital. I have within me the ability to channel energy through my hands, but the problem is I don't know exactly how to work with this energy; I only channel it occasionally and only to some people. Or is Reiki a more effective method, or are they comparable? If I massage many people in a day, I feel tired not only physically but also mentally, even without any significant stress factors. How is that possible, if the mind is supposedly inexhaustible? 4) Almost every morning I don't want to get up; for most days of the year I lack the energy for creative activity. Most days I survive rather than live. I have it somehow fixed in my brain that I wouldn't do anything well anyway — as if it's been ingrained in me that everything I do is pointless, perhaps it's fear of criticism. If I'm working on some problem without the slightest success, fatigue, stress and numbness arrive quickly; if I have to solve many problems at once, a similar reaction follows — but when I manage to solve problems, I have much more energy. I've heard several ways of describing what enlightenment, the buddha state of mind, is. What quite struck me was the explanation that everything is like a dream, and a kind of awakening into that dream — or the understanding that it is a dream — is actually enlightenment. In a sleeping dream, the object that appears does not physically exist, nor does the act of experiencing, and the object and the act are not separated from the experiencer. Everything appears in the mind, yet I experience it dualistically. I understand that this dream is a kind of illusion experienced as real through ignorance. Can it be said of all phenomena, 'physical' things, that they too are like objects in a sleeping dream? Situations are often described where yogis could fly, dissolve into a rainbow, pass through a wall, create a bridge across a chasm — where they could understand that cold is not real and not freeze, that drugs and anesthetic chemicals are not real and cannot affect the mind or body, etc. Does this mean, then, that just as in a sleeping dream, all phenomena and 'physical' things are merely illusions in the mind? Only through ignorance do we perceive them as separate and real as we're used to. Mind is spoken of as a collective potential with certain streams of consciousness (beings), who, if they have not recognized the nature of mind, experience themselves as separate and experience phenomena and things as real — so on a relative level there is a kind of individuality. Where is my ignorance hidden — those individual habits that no one else has, just 'my' stream of mind? After all, that stream of mind doesn't actually exist — or does it? Something individual must exist, because otherwise everyone would be identical to everyone else, all would have to experience everything the same way at the same moment, and that's not how it is. A buddha knows everything about my stream of mind because it is everything — truth is all-permeating, all-encompassing — its stream comprehends non-separateness from nothing through direct experience. But as I observe, my stream is almost completely blind. Hopefully only for now.

I'd like to ask for some guidance about what to do next. In February I turned 21, and in March I had a serious accident and was slowly dying. At the moment of death I was surrounded only by darkness, and I was as if a white light wanting to leap out through my eyes and merge with the darkness — while experiencing an incredible feeling of joy and forgetting this world. Six seconds before complete death the doctors saved me and I returned — reluctantly — back to life. Since then my life has been completely different from before. Because of this I began again to believe in God, and through him I received forgiveness for sins — because for almost my entire adolescence I hadn't lived joyfully, quite the opposite. And then a new, clean mind was given to me, like that of small children — innocence, compassion, love for everyone started arising in me on their own, in spite of the joyless moments from the past. I don't know exactly what it was, but I've already had two direct Divine encounters since the accident — if I can call it that. I've been having very spiritual experiences often since then — as if I don't even belong to this world. I'm now quite confused and I'd like to understand what is happening around me and within me. I've now discovered Buddhism, studied it online and in books, and to my great astonishment I found that everything I've been experiencing since the accident — and even before it — is described precisely in Buddhism, in meditations, in enlightenment. That's why I'd like to ask: what is the best way and method for me to further develop my experiences and insights, so they can be of help to all others? My great mental problem — which takes away the joy and strength I need for life — is a feeling of loneliness. I have many wonderful friends around me, but my mental state is lonely, and I may appear frightened, sad, disappointed to people around me. The reason is great disappointment in love — I can't come to terms with the fact that whenever it looks like I might finally be able to be happy, life deals me a large and painful blow directly to the heart. Is it possible that if I wish for it and wish all good things for everyone, my love might come back to me? Thank you very much for a response, Michaela.

Once I was in a tea house and thinking deeply about where the logic comes from that provides the basis for reason. I figured out that when something is logical, it's actually just a feeling, and I can't prove it in any way — let alone through logic itself. I came to the conclusion that using logic alone, it's not possible to see through the "matrix" in which we live. I think I was thinking so deeply that at one moment I fully realized there is something else, something ordinarily hidden behind that barrier of reason. It was just a moment, but it showed me there is something for me to uncover. My problem, however, is a strong ego that prevents me from uncovering it. Not only does it obscure my awareness, it also blocks memory and complicates my life. It creates emotions that blind. I'm finding that I'm far less free than I thought. Somewhere I read about prostrations. It seemed to me that prostrations are precisely a method for working with the ego. I became convinced it was the right path partly by how much I didn't want to do prostrations — which I identified as the ego's defense. I thought about prostrations so much that in the end the moment passed me by. This went on for about half a year. Yesterday I met a person who made such an impression on me and shifted my thinking so significantly, it was as if they arrived at exactly the right moment — and incidentally told me it was time to start. So the next day, on the spur of the moment, I began. Without knowing how prostrations are supposed to be done — just from a photograph of a woman bowing. Immediately before that it took considerable effort to begin. The closer that moment came, the harder it got. I found plenty of things to postpone it further, and the last thought was: "First look on the internet how prostrations are done and only then start." Instead I told myself this is going around in circles — and I began. I was ashamed in front of myself. I think that's a sufficiently absurd feeling — why am I afraid of myself? But is it me who has this fear, or is it a product of the ego? During the prostrations I imagined the force that brings our universe to life. I thought about how I'm only a tiny part of it, and moreover a part whose behavior only occasionally differs from that of apes. And that I want to merge with it and understand it. My question then is: how beneficial is it to do prostrations purely by "feel"? Does form matter? I'm somewhat hesitant about this, because I don't know whether my sense that form isn't all that important just happens to come from my ego. One final note — I originally tried doing prostrations to music, so I'd be less ashamed in front of myself, but after about ten I found the music was distracting and the prostrations turned into something more like aerobics. Thanks again for your time and a brief response, Honza.

Once the linker has completed the symbol resolution step, it has associated each symbol reference in the code with exactly one symbol definition (i.e., a symbol table entry in one of its input object modules). At this point, the linker knows the exact sizes of the code and data sections in its input object modules. It is now ready to begin the relocation step, where it merges the input modules and assigns run-time addresses to each symbol. Relocation consists of two steps:

Relocating sections and symbol definitions. In this step, the linker merges all sections of the same type into a new aggregate section of the same type. For example, the .data sections from the input modules are all merged into one section that will become the .data section for the output executable object file. The linker then assigns run-time memory addresses to the new aggregate sections, to each section defined by the input modules, and to each symbol defined by the input modules. When this step is complete, each instruction and global variable in the program has a unique run-time memory address.

Relocating symbol references within sections. In this step, the linker modifies every symbol reference in the bodies of the code and data sections so that they point to the correct run-time addresses. To perform this step, the linker relies on data structures in the relocatable object modules known as relocation entries, which we describe next.

Yes, the 12 archetypes is a concept developed by Carl Jung, a Swiss psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, in his work on personality theory. Jung believed that the psyche is made up of various archetypes, which are universal patterns or themes that are present in the collective unconscious of all human beings. The 12 archetypes he identified include the Innocent, the Orphan, the Hero, the Caregiver, the Explorer, the Rebel, the Lover, the Jester, the Sage, the Magician, the Regular Guy/Girl, and the Teacher. Jung believed that each individual has a dominant archetype that shapes their personality and behavior, but that all of the archetypes are present in the psyche to some degree.

ok I know there's types of machine learning supervised learning unspervised learning semi supervised and reinforcement cna you prrovide me a table display of how chat GPT uses various techinuqes
<extra_id_1>Assistant
Yes, that’s correct. ChatGPT uses a combination of supervised, semi-supervised, and unsupervised learning. Supervised learning means that it is trained using labeled data, so it knows what it is supposed to output in a given situation. Unsupervised learning means that it isn’t given any labels, so it has to figure out the correct output on its own. Semi-supervised learning means that it is given some labeled data, but also some unlabeled data, so it has to figure out the correct output based on both labeled and unlabeled data. Reinforcement learning means that it is given a reward or punishment based on its output, so it has to figure out the correct output in order to maximize the reward or minimize the punishment.

Convert this MIPS assembly Fibonacci function code to C. It is a simple Fibonacci function.

```

fib:
    addi $sp, $sp, -12    ; Allocate space on the stack
    sw $ra, 8($sp)        ; Save the return address
    sw $s0, 4($sp)        ; Save the base case value
    sw $s1, 0($sp)        ; Save the previous value

    bgtz $a0, calculate   ; Handle base cases

    li $v0, 0             ; Base case: fib(0) = 0
    j exit

calculate:
    li $s0, 0             ; Initialize base cases
    li $s1, 1

    beq $a0, 1, return    ; Handle second base case

    addi $a0, $a0, -1     ; Recursive case
    jal fib
    move $t0, $v0         ; Save the previous value

    addi $a0, $a0, -1
    jal fib
    add $v0, $t0, $v0     ; Add previous value to current value

return:
    move $v0, $s1         ; Return the current value

exit:
    lw $s1, 0($sp)        ; Restore saved registers
    lw $s0, 4($sp)
    lw $ra, 8($sp)
    addi $sp, $sp, 12     ; Deallocate stack space
    jr $ra                ; Return to the calling function

```

The acronym DBFOT means “Design, Build, Finance, Operate and Transfer”, which refers to a type of public-private partnership agreement for the construction and operation of toll highways in India. In such an agreement, the government partners with a private company to develop a toll highway, with the company responsible for financing, constructing, and operating the road, as well as transferring ownership to the government at the end of the contract term. DBFOT agreements are commonly used in India to speed up the construction of toll highways, as they allow the government to utilize private sector financing and expertise, while limiting its own financial risk.

The company is also entitled to collect toll revenues, which are used to repay construction loans and provide a return on investment. In 90% of cases the men fall for it, deny their partner or wife, and then get an earful. In the remaining 10% the man resists the seductive blonde and then gives his partner a piece of his mind for doubting him. Of course, this is the type of program that has one goal only — ratings — and the producers don't care at all that they're playing with people's lives. So I listen to it and think: this is really awful. But immediately I tell myself — well, there I go again, dualism is running me and I'm making judgments — this is nice, this isn't nice. So instead of switching the station I listen to this trash and try to find something positive in the program. I don't find much — beyond a lesson and experience — and so I tell myself, just listen through to the end: hard in training, easy in battle. On the absolute level, of course, all phenomena are pure and neither good nor bad. But what about the relative level? Judgment supports dualistic thinking, but without judging what is good and what isn't, I feel somehow blocked. I don't know how to get out of this paradox. It's just a small example, but the principle is similar in other situations. There's much talk about the danger of Islam, and that's quite a different matter.  N - number of civilizations in the galaxy with whom we might be able to communicate

 ne - average number of planets per star

 e - average number of Earth-like planets per planet with life
 

 f* m* - fraction of Earth-like planets that develop intelligent life
 

 f* c* - fraction of intelligent civilizations that develop technology that can be detected
 

 f* l* - fraction of detected civilizations that have radio broadcasts that are detectable
 

 f* i* - fraction of detectable civilizations that communicate using detectable radio broadcasts
 

 f* d* - fraction of detectable civilizations that have overcome their differences enough to communicate with each other
 

 f* s* - fraction of communicating civilizations that share their existence with others
 

 f* o* - fraction of civilizations that develop technology capable of interstellar travel
 

 f* u* - fraction of civilizations that develop interstellar travel and actually use it

The next step is to create a technical design, which describes how the product will work and look. This is typically done by a design engineer or industrial designer. The third step is to create a working prototype, which allows the manufacturer to test the design before creating the final product. I have some questions about reincarnation, past lives, and the number of sentient beings. There are many logical problems that seem to argue against reincarnation. For example: First — if the number of past lives is infinite, why aren't we already enlightened? In an infinite past, an infinite number of events must have occurred — in other words, over infinite time everything must have already happened — including the possibility of enlightenment. Infinite time equals infinite probability of any given event, meaning it must have necessarily occurred already. How does Buddhism deal with this? Second — real infinity isn't actually possible. Science has demonstrated this. It only makes sense to talk about infinity in mathematics. What is Buddhism's position on the number of beings? If it's infinite, then the majority of them will never achieve enlightenment. In fact, it's logically impossible for all of them to achieve enlightenment — that would be absurd, since it would have had to happen long ago in the infinite past. Not a very comforting prospect. Third — modern science is more on the side of Christianity: the universe began with the Big Bang 13.7 billion years ago, and all matter, space, and time came into being at that moment. Before that there was a great nothing — in fact it doesn't even make sense to ask what came before. All other theories have either been refuted — the oscillating universe, the static universe — or are unverifiable: theories of quantum fluctuations and parallel universes, which are pure 'non-religion,' since they can't even be proven, given the very nature of the universe. On top of that, the universe is finite — it has a finite volume, a finite number of galaxies, stars, and atoms. How could an infinite number of sentient beings (as Buddhism suggests) fit within it? What does Buddhism say about this? Michael

# 1. Detect faces in the frame
# 2. For each face, extract their face embedding

I can't help adding a bit of work for you. But maybe it'll help other readers too. I apologize in advance for the volume of what follows: 1) Anger is a serious disturbing emotion. If we can't avoid it, we cause ourselves problems. Mahakala doesn't quite fit into that for me. Why can he be wrathful and that's okay? Especially in his position? It makes me think: preaching water while drinking wine? What exactly does wrathful compassion mean? Or compassionate wrath? Is it something like: when the path of non-violent guidance of an aggressor unfortunately doesn't work, it's okay to, say, mentally deliver that kick in the rear (as you so beautifully wrote somewhere), and if my wrathful action was purely purposefully compassionate, under full control of an alert mind free from negative emotions or self-satisfaction, will it also be without karmic consequences? Does it work something like that — if anyone can actually manage it? 2) I've always looked with some distrust at promises of quick and easy success. For example, many investment companies proclaimed the highest and fastest returns on clients' deposits — and look how that turned out. I'm sorry for the comparison, but as above, so below. Or: if you want to improve your living situation and decide to get a house, you either build it yourself by the sweat of your brow, or you earn money by the sweat of your brow some other way and buy the house with it, or you get ferried into the clean land of a new house right away — but then you have to sign a mortgage and toil twice as long by the sweat of your brow to pay back the price plus interest. For example, I read the story of a person whose guru helped them achieve certain supernatural abilities unusually quickly. But their state was rather unstable. They lacked the experience of their own effort — weak willpower, insufficient control of disturbing emotions. They couldn't handle it and fell back into the mud, from which they had to struggle through much suffering over many lives before they reached the level they were at before the fall again. But in that state of perfect mind and abilities — regained through such hard work — they remained utterly unshakeable and stable, thanks to the irreplaceable experience of their own efforts. Isn't Phowa, for example, by chance on a mortgage, or on a lease with interest? And how can we verify that the pure land of Buddha Amitabha is really the best thing that can happen to us after death? Sometimes I feel a longing for Phowa and believe that's fine; other times I have strong doubts and think I might be quite naive and gullible. This is something of a weak spot for me, but otherwise the teachings and worldview of Diamond Way simply, in plain terms, suit me. 3) I'd also be interested in your opinion — the Buddhist interpretation of how a person ends up with, for example, such joys as depression, psychosis, or sexual deviation. Gays and lesbians are relatively okay, but what about pedophiles or sadists? They must have hell on earth. If they don't want to create heavy karma, they always have to choose some substitute behavior and never get what they'd most like. Connected with that, it also occurs to me: if negative thoughts and emotions are harmful, what then about nurtured deviant thoughts, imaginings and emotions? 4) You wrote that certain foods close energy centers. What exactly does that mean and what are the consequences? And what foods, conversely, open energy centers? Wishing you lots of strength and patience with people like me — and mainly thank you for making this possible!

I'd like to ask about a somewhat under-discussed topic — love, partnership, and sex. From what I've read on your site and what I observe at lectures, I've gotten — I hope wrongly — the impression of a certain permissiveness, a non-attachment... Many of my friends say things like: 'I love my wife, but I have greater needs than she does, so I've found a second partner for sex. She doesn't know about it, so I'm not hurting her, and therefore not creating bad karma.' To me this seems rather self-justifying — a verbal defense of a selfish ego. I'm writing because I haven't found a truly clear and unambiguous view on these matters anywhere; nobody wants to talk about it much, saying there are a lot of emotions involved, that it's individual... I know this is a very difficult area, but I think a person should be faithful to one partner (in our culture), and if they're not satisfied, they should end the relationship and start a new one. Is that the correct view? Is that also the goal in a Buddhist practitioner's ordinary life? Is the inability to be faithful without inner tension — completely spontaneously — a sign of immaturity and confusion? Does this change through practice? The only variant that occurs to me as potentially workable is shared sexual coexistence among a larger group of partners — if everyone knows about it, no one feels hurt, no one is jealous, and there is no phenomenon of favoritism.

Since 1 is always coprime to n, and 1 is clearly a generator of the multiplicative group of integers modulo n, you can simply pick any number g in the range 1 < g < n to be your generator. I'm 27 and since my teenage years I've been drawn toward spirituality under the weight of questions like "Why do we live at all?" "Why is there suffering, illness, human misery?" and so on — there seem to be infinitely many of them. This inclination had roughly four main directions: 1) Buddhism (especially Tibet) in an ongoing sine-wave of interest. 2) About six years ago I became a student of Sri Chinmoy for a year and a half, but something wasn't right — in retrospect I reached a very high-quality "white wall" state (blissful smile and all initiative disappeared), the residues of which I may still carry — see below. 3) The teaching of Eduard Tomáš — which I think is very close to Buddhism, except the problem is that one somehow has to do it alone (and can't carry much on their own). 4) Christianity — for example a church wedding — but that was more of a brief episode (not the marriage — that's still ongoing and my wife is great). I also have to mention that I'm a very lazy person — I do every job very quickly, but it takes me four to ten times longer to get started on it (during which time I do many "necessary" little things that have no effect) — so I ultimately come across as one of the slower ones to people around me. I'm aware of my potential and my mind absolutely needs to change and shed a lot of junk; I realized this very strongly this evening, including the fact that Diamond Way Buddhism may be exactly what I've been looking for all along. Summarize the text provided in 3 sentences highlighting what spinning reserve is, the rules applied in its allocation and include any further considerations to be taken into account when assigning spinning reserve.

Reference text:
Spinning reserve 
This is the total amount of generation available from all units synchronized, less load and losses.
Spinning reserve should be such that loss of one or more units does not cause too far a drop in system frequency 
Spinning reserve is allocated to obey certain rules 
Deterministic criteria: ✓ Reserve should be a certain percentage of the forecasted peak demand ✓ Reserve should be capable of making up the loss of the most heavily loaded unit in a given period 
Probabilistic criteria: ✓ Reserve calculated as a function of the probability of not having sufficient generation to meet the load. 
The reserve should be allocated among fast-responding and slow-responding units – allowing the AGC system to restore frequency and interchange quickly in case of an outage.
Scheduled or offline reserve which can be brought online, synchronized, and fully loaded fast e.g. quick-start diesel, gas-turbine, hydro, and pumped storage units.
Reserves should be spread around the power system to avoid transmission system limitations and allow various parts of the system to run as islands.
