I've been practicing for half a year — every day the Three Lights plus a practice. Everything is fine more or less, but I ran into something that confused me so much I just had to write this question. Specifically, during the Three Lights meditation. The meditation instruction says: 'Karmapa is here whether or not we can experience it clearly.' I feel that quite freely and naturally. Sometimes the openness and trust are weaker, sometimes stronger. I try to do the best I can in any given moment. Then I read the pink booklet by Tadeusz Ucht, 'On the Way the Mind Functions and Its Nature,' and in his answer to one question he says: 'during the meditation on the Karmapa, nothing is actually flowing, but right now I have the opportunity to open everything up,' 'Karmapa dissolves and merges with me, but only so that I recognize that I am Karmapa,' 'We say that Karmapa unites with us, but these are just concepts — in reality nothing like that is happening; in reality the Karmapa's blessing has been within us all along.' Sometimes this is completely clear to me and I don't think about it at all. The openness and trust are just there. But then sometimes during meditation I get stuck on this and start asking myself: 'So, is Karmapa here or not?' And at that point it becomes such a big problem, and I pick it apart for so long, that I just sit down and write this question. Am I thinking about it too much, or have I thought about it too little? On the other hand, if a model has low variance, it will fit the data you have very well, but it might not generalize very well to new data. So you want to find a model with a good balance between bias and variance.

what does it mean to attack a straw man
<extra_id_1>Assistant
Attacking a “straw man” is a fallacy of logic in which an argument is constructed that is easy to defeat, and then defeated, rather than the most powerful form of the opponent’s argument. Typically, this fallacy consists of misrepresenting the opponent’s position, and then attacking that misrepresented position. A common example of this fallacy is arguing against a “straw man” version of the opponent’s position, instead of the real position. Another example would be to prove that the opponent’s position leads to an absurdity, but this absurdity is not a part of the opponent’s position. In the latter case, this is sometimes called a “question-begging fallacy”, because the opponent’s position is assumed in order to prove that it is false, thus begging the question.
<extra_id_1>User
Assuming what needs to be proved is question begging fallacy. What's an example of that?

I read the question from Andrej from Brno and one possible answer occurs to me as well: The Karmapa lineage derives directly from Gampopa, while Gampopa was not Milarepa's only student. So it could easily have happened that there are other transmission lineages that went through someone other than Gampopa. Each of those systems then has different characteristics. Some of Milarepa's students certainly had extraordinary results — Rechungpa, for instance. He was also the one who passed some of the deepest teachings to Gampopa, since Milarepa did not do so during his own lifetime, passing them instead to other students, especially Rechungpa. The reason things are not explained at Marpa's level today is obvious: no one in the known Karma Kagyu lineage is at that level, and it would be presumptuous to even think so. The Karmapas are heirs of Gampopa's teaching — and thus represent a separate lineage of Karmapa saints, which is not a direct continuation of the Marpa school tradition. The question: Suppose the 10th Karmapa personally comes to Bratislava (it's not that far) — what if we asked him: What is the main transmission lineage of the Karmapa and what is the main transmission lineage of the Marpa school? Why does he give the Avalokiteshvara initiation? Giving such an initiation requires the realization of that state. Did Marpa give the Avalokiteshvara initiation? Or let the Karmapa himself answer — why, for example, does his "student" lama Ole not live according to Buddhist precepts? I know they had a discussion about that with Ole, during which Ole referred to following Marpa's example. So we should also ask Ole whether he feels he is at Marpa's level — or at least at the level of Marpa's student Milarepa, who himself said he would not have been capable of living as Marpa did without the diamond purity of his aims. And everyone can learn from Milarepa's biography that he was one of the most revered and greatest saints of Tibet. His qualities convinced people, gods and demons. That is certainly not visible in the Karma Kagyu lineage today. It would be sheer arrogance to consider today's people who are so devoted to the world as even approaching the perfection of someone like Milarepa. His effort, honor and glory live to this day in the hearts of those who can renounce the world as completely as he did. I maintain that the Karma Kagyu lineage should not consider itself a direct line of transmission of initiations from Marpa — and that would resolve these problems. The Karma Kagyu lineage were saints following Gampopa's teachings — they are therefore his transmission lineage. Since Gampopa did not receive the deepest teachings directly from Milarepa during his lifetime (Milarepa passed them to other students, especially Rechungpa), this should be clear to everyone. You know, Radek, when I then re-read what I've written, it reminds me of accusing Christians of dogmatic thinking. Christians also claim allegiance to Jesus and insist that Peter was his best student, while the truth is that they know nothing of that Jesus and also don't know that Peter misunderstood Jesus, and the best disciple who truly understood Jesus was John. Peter is, in the Karma Kagyu case, Gampopa, and Rechungpa is that John. I don't expect you to publish this — but at least read it. Christians also cling to their errors — just like people of other teachings — and voluntarily have no intention of giving them up.

Define a Cooperative Process in OS. What are the three criteria a critical section problem solution needs to satisfy?
<extra_id_1>Assistant
A cooperative process in OS is a program that allows other programs to execute in an interleaved manner. Critical section problems are synchronization problems that occur when multiple processes need to access shared resources simultaneously. Solutions to critical section problems need to satisfy three criteria: mutual exclusion, progress, and starvation-freedom. Mutual exclusion ensures that at most one process can be in a critical section at any given time. Progress ensures that eventually some process will be able to enter a critical section. Starvation-freedom prevents a process from being continuously pre-empted from entering a critical section.
<extra_id_1>User
Write and explain the Readers-Writers problem solution. Or
 Explain Reader-Writers problem solution using Semaphores
<extra_id_1>Assistant
The Readers-Writers problem is a synchronization problem that occurs when multiple readers or writers need to access shared resources simultaneously. The solution is based on the use of semaphores, which are synchronization primitives that allow processes to wait for and signal that a shared resource is available. The Readers-Writers problem solution uses two semaphores, one for readers and one for writers. Readers are allowed to acquire the reader semaphore and access the shared resource simultaneously, as long as no writers are waiting for the resource. Writers are allowed to acquire the writer semaphore and access the shared resource simultaneously, as long as no readers are waiting for the resource. This solution satisfies the three criteria for critical section problems: mutual exclusion, progress, and starvation-freedom.

Red shifting can happen due to gravity or if something is moving away from us. Is that right?
<extra_id_1>Assistant
Yes, both gravitational red shift and Doppler red shift can occur. In the case of gravitational red shift, this happens when light is emitted from a high gravitational potential (near a massive object) to a lower potential (farther away from the massive object), causing the light to appear redder as it travels away from the massive object due to the gravitational potential difference. In the case of Doppler red shift, this happens when a source of light (such as a star) is moving towards us, causing the light to appear redder as it gets closer due to the Doppler effect. Alternatively, if the source of light is moving away from us, the light will appear bluer as it gets farther away due to the same Doppler effect.

Return of Rome is a completely new type of expansion, which brings classic Age of Empires gameplay, style and key experiences as a brand new self-contained experience.

The Lac Viet are an additional civilization playable alongside the 16 classic civilizations in Return of Rome.

Civilization Bonuses

Foragers work 20% faster
Military units created 25% faster
Archery Range units +2 armor
Team Bonus

Houses and Farms built 50% faster
The Romans in Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition
The Romans were intended as a bonus for you to enjoy in Singleplayer and Unranked Lobbies as an extra, on top of the content within Return of Rome.

However, we’ve been listening to your feedback and desire to see Romans as a ranked civilization. Based on that feedback, we have decided to add Romans to the ranked queue in a future update. Hey, I have a little question. Before I got into Buddhism, I was into esotericism — and there this idea was heavily promoted that the body is an image of the mind (using the word 'mind' a bit differently, of course), and therefore if something is wrong with the body, it follows that something is wrong with the mind too. But then I learned that some Karmapa died of cancer, so that probably can't be true. I'd like to know what Buddhism's view on illness is. Is it just an illusion not worth dealing with at all (like when you're playing a game and your arm gets shot off and you just keep going without noticing)? Or is it somewhat meaningful — for example, being healthy means your mind is healthy too? I'm asking all this because after a long time I went to the dentist and they found 11 cavities, plus a piece of a molar had broken off — and I'm only 20. I hadn't been to the dentist for a long time because my teeth didn't hurt and they looked fine. In esotericism they say that when your teeth decay or fall out, it means you can't 'chew through' your problems, or that you're losing vitality. And while I'm writing — something else comes to mind. My grandfather was diagnosed with lung cancer plus metastases God knows where (that last bit is just a figure of speech, of course). And now watching him get worse day by day — he finds fault in everything, criticizes everything, goes on about all the wrongs life has dealt him, and so on. I'm asking how to help him. In other words: is there any point in saying anything to him? Because I feel like there isn't. I'll also add that he is a believer, though I think it's more out of habit. The booklet contained several pornographic images and a glossary of terminology used in the gay community. It was sold for 25 cents a copy, with a discount for bulk orders of 100 copies or more.[1]

The Johns Committee had for several years conducted a witch hunt for homosexuals in public schools, universities, and state government agencies, believing they were part of a Communist strategy to "subvert the American way of life by controlling academic institutions and by corrupting the nation's moral fiber." Can you help me understand something? In comparing Hinayana and Mahayana or Vajrayana, I've heard that Hinayana is for those who want to help themselves, while the other schools are for those who want to help others. It seems to me that no person can have only their own wellbeing in mind and simultaneously feel themselves to be part of the whole — to perceive the interconnection that Buddhism emphasizes. It also seems to me that if I want to be helpful to others, I must be able to see their suffering, be capable of empathy, and therefore develop compassion; be able to assess circumstances and thus develop clear perception; and also use wisdom to intervene effectively — or to not intervene. For this I must first develop certain capacities and a certain way of perceiving the world within myself, which is in effect helping myself — and only then can I help others effectively. I also think that by living alongside other beings we mutually influence each other, and therefore, if my influence is positive thanks to my own worldview, that in itself is already help. After all, my own life alone can be an example for another that keeps them afloat, or can even arouse their interest in my way of seeing the world. From this it seems to me that I cannot separate helping myself from helping other beings, and therefore I cannot separate Buddhist schools from each other on the basis of such surface definitions. Am I wrong?

The thought was expressed there that 'the only path to victory is to refuse to fight.' I don't know why, but I immediately thought of Buddhism. And something slightly simplified and different in meaning: not to resist evil with force. Then the name Gandhi came to mind, and what he achieved. And then we started developing the idea of how non-violence actually works — and of refusing to fight. How does Buddhism look at this? Because there are moments when a person must defend themselves, and when confronted with violence or a fight they cannot run away — so how can they avoid it? How should a person respond — I'd be interested in the perspective of your teaching. By the way, at school we studied Buddhism along with other philosophical and religious directions. I don't know why, but somehow I was left with the impression of a passive approach to the surrounding world — but when I looked at it on Wikipedia it didn't seem so passive anymore. It struck me that Buddhism bows deeply before the greatness of the universe, acknowledges that a person can never fully know it, and yet doesn't throw in the towel — what seems important is that a person, according to their abilities, should know and do as much as possible. That's just my opinion, of course, and everything is more complex. But unlike some other religions, in Buddhism it seems nothing is dogmatically fixed — on the contrary, everything is to be examined and discovered. I may not have it quite right, but I liked that. Please, if you can — how does refusing to fight lead to victory?

I have a kind of problem. Many years ago I had an abortion. At the time I perceived abortion as a completely acceptable option for someone who doesn't want a child, and it was much later that I saw what an embryo actually looks like during and after an abortion and realized it's already a sentient human being. Even then it bothered me deeply that I would allow and go through with something like that, but at the same time I couldn't imagine having a child with that sexual partner. It was clear to me that I'd be going into motherhood without him, and since I'd personally experienced a lot from the absence of a father in my life, I couldn't imagine how I would one day explain to my child that its father exists somewhere in the world, but I'm not with him and don't want contact and don't really know much about him. My internal conflict was deepened by the fact that at that time I had a very strong sense that my life was firmly in my own hands, and suddenly something derailed that concept. I was very diligent about contraception and couldn't understand how it could have happened to me at all. So many girls are careless about protection and I — the careful one — got pregnant? But most of all I couldn't accept the thought that I would actually go through with it (meaning the abortion). At one point I was unequivocally decided to keep the child, but then the child's father behaved very violently in a conflict — he started strangling me in an argument — and I gradually began to fear it wouldn't be so easy to disappear from his field of vision. Which later turned out to be a stupid worry, because when I stopped seeing him he left me alone. I was heavily swayed by my family's attitude; they made it very clear they had no intention of supporting me in the role of single mother. Much later I understood those were just strong words, and in the end they certainly would have helped me, but at the time I truly believed them. In the end I went through the abortion with the joyful support of my family, but for a long time I couldn't come to terms with it, and for years I had no partner. Later I thought it was all behind me, but ever since I started taking an interest in Buddhism it gradually began to dawn on me how deeply a sense of guilt is embedded in my mind, and how in fact I've been punishing myself the whole time for what I did — something I never identified with. Essentially everything bad that ever happened to me I took as a just punishment for what I had done, even though I was completely unaware of it. The feeling that I deserve negative things only became fully conscious to me after I decided to start practicing. I'm now preparing to take refuge with Ole in the summer and I'm doing the Three Lights meditation. Is there anything else I could do to be able to move forward and at the same time somehow "make amends" for what I did? Thank you in advance for any reply. I'm sorry I don't say who I am, but I can't present my problem completely publicly; even publishing it like this doesn't leave me entirely comfortable, though I hope it might help someone else who reads both the question and the answer.

Yes, Floyd-Warshall algorithm works on undirected graphs. It finds shortest paths between all pairs of nodes in the graph, by repeatedly updating shortest path distances using the shortest paths found so far. It does this using a “three-pass” algorithm, where it performs three iterations of updating shortest paths.

In this example, several transcription errors could occur, including:
 

 1) Phonetic errors - This type of error results from the transcription program not being able to correctly recognize the speech patterns in the sentence. For example, if the speaker pronounced the word "doing" with a long "o" sound, the transcribed text might read "doin'."
 

 2) Omissions - This type of error occurs when the speech-to-text program fails to transcribe an entire word or phrase. For example, if the speaker paused briefly before saying "today," the transcribed text might read "how are you doing today."
 

 3) Insertions - This type of error occurs when the speech-to-text program transcribes an extra word or phrase that was not actually spoken. For example, if the speaker pronounced the word "doing" with a short "o" sound, the transcribed text might read "Hi, how are you doing today?"

Here, in effect, is an ecological contradiction lodged at the heart of capitalist society—in the relation this society establishes between economy and nature. Grounded deep in the system’s structure, this contradiction is encapsulated in four words that begin with the letter d: dependence, division, dis-avowal, and destabilization. In a nutshell: capitalist society makes “economy” depend on “nature,” while dividing them ontologically. Enjoining maximal accumulation of value, while defining nature as not partaking of it, this arrangement programs economy to disavow the ecological reproduction costs it generates. The effect, as those costs mount exponentially, is to destabilize ecosystems—and, periodically, to disrupt the entire jerry-rigged edifice of capitalist society. Simultaneously needing and rubbishing nature, capitalism is in this respect, too, a cannibal that devours
its own vital organs. Like the ouroboros, it eats its own tail

And that’s a shame. Why is reading important? Studies have shown that a regular reading habit not only sharpens vocabulary and improves IQ, but also reduces the brain’s rate of decline in old age and expands “EQ”—emotional intelligence and well-being.

Those are all good reasons to establish early reading habits in children and nurture them well into adulthood. But according to a recent Gallup survey, reading is on the decline. American adults read (either all or part of the way) an average of 12.6 books during the past year, fewer than any year since the firm began asking in 1990. Perhaps most striking, however, is the fact that the decline is greater in groups that have historically been among the biggest readers: college graduates, women and older Americans.

In positive news, while the number of books Americans are reading is trending down, the survey found that the percentage of American adults who are reading has remained steady since 2002. If you don’t count yourself in that group, don’t stress. It’s never too late to adopt a reading habit that’ll broaden your mind and enrich your life. Whether you’re studiously making your way through the best books of all time or just taking 20 minutes a day to read the latest bestselling mystery novel, the benefits of being one of America’s bookworms are boundless.

Not long ago you answered Adela, saying "time is a product of the mind and as such does not exist; only the moment of here and now exists in reality. The past is already gone, the future hasn't happened yet, the present moment escapes the moment we focus on it — time does not exist." For some reason, from various inputs I've gathered from reading the history of the Karmapas and the Dharma in general, I can't quite believe that. To be specific — I agree with you that time is a product of the mind and perhaps mainly of the mind housed in a physical body (i.e., a being). I disagree that the past is already gone and the future hasn't yet arrived (I have no doubts about the present moment). The thing is that the Karmapa is able, during meditation before his death, to find his future life and describe it in a letter that is meant to be opened only at a specific moment he expressly wished for — and which he also apparently predicts. So I have two reflections here: the first is that the Karmapa has the ability to move in meditation into future time and see what he needs; or, second, he identifies in meditation the parents he wants to be born to, and this happens in the present time — so he doesn't look into the future at all. My view is that the future and the past should be reachable in meditation, at any distance. It's still just a feeling I can't quite grasp yet. Right now the following occurs to me — and I admit it might be an exaggerated thought: if the past were hypothetically NOTHING that arose after SOMETHING, and conversely the future were also NOTHING but waiting for SOMETHING, one could then speak of there being both nothing and something. Is the mind then something with a beginning and end in the present? And then there's the Dharma, which says that time is actually a product of the mind — so hypothetically, if the mind in the present creates a scenario for the future, then that very present unfolds according to a scenario that was written in the past. Isn't it rather that time genuinely exists just as the mind genuinely exists, but the way anyone or anything perceives time is the individual expression of the mind? Provide the equation of a circle with a radius of 5 and center at (1, -2). You must provide the equation in [Latex] format.
Solution:
A circle with center at (h, k) and radius r has the equation:
(x - h)^2 + (y - k)^2 = r^2
In this case, the center is (1, -2) and the radius is 5. So, the equation of the circle is:
(x - 1)^2 + (y + 2)^2 = 25
Rewritten in Latex format:
\[(x-1)^2 + (y+2)^2 = 25\]

We need cryptography to keep information secret and secure, so that only intended recipients can read it. more

Cryptography is also used in applications such as digital signatures and key exchange, which are used for secure electronic transactions.

I'd like to ask for your advice. Lately, during an ordinary day of going to work and meeting friends, two kinds of periods alternate for me. The first is quite a pleasant experience or way of being: I'm relaxed, balanced, spontaneous, can enjoy myself among people, do my work well both at work and at home — basically wonderful. But then all it takes is something trivial — someone sends me an email I might misread — and I start obsessing over it (it doesn't have to be an email; anything else, like an unfriendly look from someone toward me, works the same way). Even when I know that it's more my fault than anyone else's, I can't immediately let it go and not let it disturb me — I'm pulled along by the stream of thoughts it produces in me. In those moments I can't meditate, can't relax; all I do is wait for it to pass, and sometimes that takes hours or even days. My question is: why, when I often manage to rest in the present moment for stretches of several days, am I unable to hold onto that understanding? Are there any protective methods for this — such as Mahakala? Thank you in advance.

I have a larger question — I'd like to ask whether my perspective is correct. I think that a person's life is determined by what happens in their inner world (thoughts, images, feelings...) and in the outer world (people, weather, various situations, etc.). If a person is dependent — in varying degrees — on this inner and outer world, the more their life is weaker, their inner strength or freedom lesser, and they are more of a puppet that is lived rather than truly living. Conversely, if a person is very independent of this inner and outer experience, the greater their 'distance,' the greater their freedom and inner strength, and their life is much richer. To summarize: to the extent that the mind understands all things as spontaneous and inevitable, to that extent it has power over them and therefore is less subject to them. (Baruch Spinoza.) Is this view in harmony with Buddhism? Can one think of enlightenment as a kind of absolute distance — the ability to see all events, inner and outer, as spontaneous? As a more or — infinitely — meaningful play of space? Or is it something even more than that? Also: is it sufficient, given the above, to practice the capacity for 'self-awareness' and develop inner freedom — to observe with distance what is happening in the mind and to be aware of the above perspective on enlightenment?

In other words, why, if we are all inwardly buddhas, did we leave that beautiful state and create this world full of suffering (or, if suffering is conditioned and dependent on our perception — an illusion of suffering)? I assume that if Buddha Shakyamuni is now experiencing infinite joy, he probably won't one day change his mind, decide he's bored, appear in this world, veil his radiance with ego, and begin harming himself and others. Something that has reached the highest state is inwardly perfect and loving — it logically cannot (and has no reason to) ruin this joy for itself and others by creating egos that produce a world in which they begin killing one another. Why does a radiant diamond wrap itself in dirt? (I think there are two possibilities: 1. We are not inwardly perfect but divided. 2. Prior to Descartes, several other philosophers had expressed related ideas, but Descartes was the first to present this view in a systematic and widely recognized manner.

Hi!  I am developing a system called Faunal Calculus that applies mathematical operations to animal species.  It is very abstract and silly and currently has no logical consistency.  I would like you to help me make it consistent.  While we chat today, I would like you to give me short answers so we can iterate quickly.

 I'll start with some examples, along with my reasoning:
1. Snail ÷ Turtle = Worm
The most iconic visual features of both a turtle and a snail are their shells.  If you remove that quality from the snail, you would end up with something that's just slimy and long, like a worm.

2. Ant + Frog = Grasshopper
if you add the frog's green-ness and jumpiness to an ant, you get a grasshopper.

3. Weasel - Mouse = Snake
If you remove the mouse-ness (small, furry mammal) from a weasel, you end up with just the long, slithery qualities, like a snake.

And now, some rules:
i. Faunal Calculus only includes real animals which have existed at some point in time (no mythological creatures
ii. Faunal Calculus does not include any hybrid species such as Ligers or Zorses.
iii. Faunal Calculus focuses on the most iconic, visual features of the animal, rather than behavior characteristics, or more general qualities like "gracefulness."
iii. every equation must account for the most iconic visual features of each animal.  For example: Horse + Leopard = Giraffe is incorrect (even though the horse and giraffe share a similar body type and the giraffe and the Leopard share the feature of having spots) because it does not account for the source of the Giraffe's long neck.
iv. The visual characteristics must be accounted for in a visual manner.  For example, the Giraffe's long neck cannot only be considered for its beauty and uniqueness, but must specifically be considered for its length.

Packet sniffing is the passive monitoring of network traffic, in order to collect data about network activity. These techniques are commonly used for network security purposes. A popular tool for both packet scanning and sniffing is Wireshark. Another popular tool for packet scanning is Nmap.

<extra_id_1>Assistant
That’s a tricky question! It depends a lot on what you mean by “easier”. I’d say R is generally more popular right now, but that’s probably because it’s more accessible to people who don’t have a statistics background. It’s a little easier to pick up in that sense, and it has more libraries and pre-built packages for various tasks. But SAS is used more often in the pharmaceutical and CRO (contract research organization) industries, and has been around longer.  
 

 So, in terms of learning the basics of the languages, I’d say R is probably a little easier, since it’s more “user-friendly”, but if you want to do something complicated, SAS might be a better choice.

What is CRO in regards to pharmaceutical
<extra_id_1>Assistant
CROs are contract research organizations. They’re basically companies that do clinical trials and other studies for pharmaceutical companies. They’re paid by the pharmaceutical company to do the study, and they manage all the logistics and data collection. The pharmaceutical company then analyzes the data and writes up the results.
<extra_id_1>User
Why do Pharmaceuticals choose to use them? What's the value proposition?
<extra_id_1>Assistant
Pharma companies choose to use CROs for two reasons. First, they can focus on the science and the drug development, and not have to worry about all the logistics of running a clinical trial. And second, they get a lot of the data collection and analysis work done for them, so they don’t have to hire a bunch of statisticians and programmers to do that. They can just outsource it. And some CROs are very good at it, so it can actually help improve the quality of the data.

Don't you think it would be appropriate and right to stop using this improper, demeaning, disrespectful, and misleading term? Do you really think it's good to call the Buddha's noble Eightfold Path — the Middle Way, perfectly and thoroughly explained and elaborated in the original texts — a 'small' or 'inferior' path? Those texts record that a great number of the Buddha's finest disciples, immediately after hearing the Master's teaching, attained one of the four stages of awakening, and many of them subsequently (within a very short time — days or weeks) reached the highest fourth stage: the final and unsurpassable goal — Nibbana (Release) or Arahantship (Supreme Worthiness). Is it really right to call such a teaching a small, low, slow, or lengthy path? Is it not perhaps offensive and disrespectful toward the Buddha, his Dhamma, and the original Sangha? Is not the Buddha's noble Eightfold Path itself sufficiently 'great' (Mahayana) and sufficiently 'diamond-like' (Vajrayana) — and not in the least inferior (Hinayana)? Is it not a confusing myth to claim that the noble Eightfold Path is merely a slow and laborious method of following ethical rules, suitable only for less intelligent and less capable individuals? Is not the observance of ethical rules just one (albeit necessary) partial component of this perfect and complete Eightfold Path — and not its entire essence?

In Buddhism it's said that a person shouldn't react with negative emotions — if you feel negative emotions arising you should let them be until your mind calms down. At least that's how I understood it. But what should I do when I feel wronged or feel some injustice? Usually in that moment I'm overtaken by terrible anger at that person, and I don't feel well. I don't want to give that anger free rein because I'm afraid it would all end very badly. So I often do nothing, because at that moment I'm simply not capable of thinking rationally. How can my mind calm down in that moment when I feel someone is attacking me? I've been practicing Buddhism for four years. Before I came to practical Buddhism I had general information about it available through the media — mainly because of the Dalai Lama, whom I've always greatly respected, and Buddhism likewise. For many years I was very confused; I didn't know why I exist and what I am. Since youth I've known that suffering exists — I perceive it even when everything looks relatively fine. I also always said: I am not what you see, I am the "someone" who lives in this body. The result was that I preferred to stop telling anyone anything and closed in on myself. I've been living with all of this inside me for many years already. (I can already see a fifth cross on my back, and I have adult children.) When I came to living Buddhism and the texts, I felt as if I had stepped from a freezing blizzard into a warm and cozy home, and I didn't doubt the Dharma for even a second. The Dharma answered many of my questions and I believe it will answer the rest too. I have no problem — and never have, since youth — with my own death; I simply don't fear it. I have no problem — and never have — with aging and illness. Other poisons such as anger, envy, jealousy... they do appear, but I manage to eliminate them quickly before they manifest outwardly. Attachment to children and home is quite strong in me. And now the question: My greatest problem is fear — but not fear of the dark, of my boss or anything like that. In essence in this life I have no serious fear of anything and I'm certain that with the Dharma I'll handle it fine to the end. My great — and growing — fear is of the next rebirth. I don't feel I have enough strength for more samsaric "monkey business," for more losing battles with suffering. I need to rest and gather strength; then perhaps I'll be capable of continuing the struggle. I don't know how much longer I'll live, and so I must do "SOMETHING" sufficiently powerful to preserve clear consciousness and free will in the bardo of death, where I could choose a "longer health leave" and after recovery and gathering strength continue further in samsara — so that from the first moments I'd have contact with the Dharma and wouldn't be "floundering" for a few decades in ignorance. What should I do?

The request status server pattern is used for communicating the status of an async request between an app and a server. The request status server is a simple server that exposes an endpoint for querying the status of a request. The app sends a request to the server, and the server responds with the request status. The app can then monitor the request status to determine when the request is complete.

I'd like to ask about something that caught my attention. I'll say upfront that I'm not a Buddhist, but my brother is and we occasionally discuss various topics. Yesterday I looked at your website for the first time and happened to read the introduction — the key terms — and I was struck by this statement: "What is the significance of the teacher? The popular Western notion of achieving enlightenment alone cannot compare to the rapid success of complete practice with a teacher or in a group. Although achieving enlightenment alone sounds very appealing to the modern person who feels master of their own life, it presents too many pitfalls. Understanding the mind is far more treacherous than studying external phenomena, and enemies in the form of pride and displeasure always lurk, capable of derailing a given individual's development. The highest level of teaching cannot be properly understood or maintained without a teacher. If the communication that neutralizes pride, sentimentality and superficiality is absent, a person can become lonely or useless in everyday life. The lama uses methods to develop the potential of his students, enabling them to push through layers of habitual behavior. The lama's role is to make his students independent, compassionate and strong. At the highest level he allows his students to enter the fearless mirror-hall of his mind. Once they then discover that they share the same nature, there is nothing left to find out." I couldn't understand from what position you claim that something cannot compare to something else. My brother wasn't able to answer me, which is why I'm asking here. I agree that there are many pitfalls — such is life. I don't want to separate life from spiritual life, but how do you know that progress will be faster with a teacher or in a group? I don't want to analyze the very notion of progress here, which I also consider misguided — that's for a longer discussion. How do you know it's not possible to maintain the final state without a teacher? Again I don't want to discuss what maintaining a final state means since I don't quite understand it, but what interests me is: where does your certainty come from that what you believe is good, and that what you believe should be achieved, is somehow better with a teacher? Who can claim this? And please don't say an enlightened person, because then that person couldn't view things in an enlightened way if they made such a claim — it would be asserting that something is better than something else, which is dualism, isn't it? Please understand, I don't want to argue — I'm just struck by the above. Who gave you this patent? I have nothing against Buddhism, it just smells a bit like selling spirituality. You know, if it said that the meaning of a teacher is only to advise when I want to be guided, nothing could be objected to, but this invites debate. Maybe you'll object that your Buddhist experience is such, but what if other experiences are completely different? And wasn't the Buddha himself an example of the denial of the above? He didn't need a teacher — was he somehow exceptional? My view is that he was not. I'll add that I'm not a follower of any teaching. Thanks in advance for the response.

When I read the article about the nature of dreams (in the introduction to Buddhism section — everyday life), I remembered one of my own experiences. The last paragraph talks about becoming aware of a dream. Some time ago I was having a lot of discussions generally about awareness. When I asked whether anyone had become aware of a dream while inside the dream, no one responded. This question stemmed from my own personal experience. It happened not once, but exactly three times. During sleep, while dreaming, I became aware that I was in a dream and began to actively influence my mind. I don't know how to describe it better, but I'll try. I was no longer just the passive observer (as is usual), going through a dream, not understanding why this or that happened in it, waking up and forgetting it within a few minutes. Instead I became an active "player," and awareness gave my mind an incredible freedom. For example, when a person dreams of standing on a window ledge with a deep abyss below, the survival instinct kicks in, fear and trembling set in, and many people wake up sweating. From my experience it was the opposite. Becoming aware of the dream freed me from fear. And I would, for example, without worry start padding, running along the ledge, or perhaps with a smile take a step into the void without fear. The article says that most of the time we aren't able to maintain this experience or remember it. I remember it, and I remember how I woke up — through awareness of the dream you can also consciously regulate waking: if you want to wake up within the dream, you wake up immediately. It left such a strong and inexplicable impression that I wanted to experience it again and go further on the path of knowing the mind. I fell asleep and consciously returned to the dream again. It's like being physically in a reality of unlimited possibilities. I was never able to explain it to myself, nor did I find understanding in anyone, because discussing something completely unknown isn't really a discussion. I found no one who could tell me anything about it. That's why I was greatly surprised by the article, which for the first time from a source other than myself described what I had experienced. Do you think you could point me to some literature on this topic? Because I'd like to develop this within myself and better understand it. Or even some reaction from your own knowledge is fine. Thank you for any response. With regards, Hana.

Suppose A=F/K is an abelian group, where F is free. Suppose A is also a subgroup of another abelian group B. Must there exist abelian groups K' and F' with the following properties? 1) K' and F are both contained in F' ; 2) F'/F is free; 3) K \subseteq K'; 4) the intersection of K' with F is equal to K; 5) the inclusion map from A to B can be viewed as the map from F/K to F'/K' defined by mapping x+K to x+K' (which is well defined and injective because of 3 and 4)
<extra_id_1>Assistant
Yes, this is true. In fact, this can be proved using the following standard argument:
 

 First, by an application of the Jordan-Hölder theorem, there exist abelian groups K' and F' such that A=F/K is a quotient of F' by K', and F'/F is a free abelian group. Then by an application of the First Isomorphism Theorem, we have F'=FK'+F, so F/F' is a quotient of F/K, which is abelian. Therefore, F/F' is a torsion abelian group, and so is a quotient of Z/nZ for some positive integer n. Then F'=F(Z/nZ)=FZ/nZ, so the inclusion map from A to B can be viewed as the map from F/K to F'/K' defined by mapping x+K to x+K' (which is well defined and injective because of 3 and 4).

This method helps companies to identify the most profitable customers by analyzing customers’ value across different business functions, such as sales, marketing, customer service, etc. It is based on the assumption that there are four distinct categories of customers with varying profitability:
 

  
 

 High Profitability (A) – These customers have high profits and a high potential for future growth. These are the customers you want to focus your sales efforts on.
 

 Moderate Profitability (B) – These customers have moderate profits, but have the potential for future growth. Focus your sales efforts on these customers to increase their profitability.
 

 Low Profitability (C) – These customers have low profits and a low potential for future growth. These customers are likely to be unprofitable for your company, so you should try to reduce costs associated with servicing them.

Given a data stream input of non-negative integers `a1, a2, ..., an`, summarize the numbers seen so far as a list of disjoint intervals.

Implement the `SummaryRanges` class:

*   `SummaryRanges()` Initializes the object with an empty stream.
*   `void addNum(int value)` Adds the integer `value` to the stream.
*   `int[][] getIntervals()` Returns a summary of the integers in the stream currently as a list of disjoint intervals `[starti, endi]`. The answer should be sorted by `starti`.

**Example 1:**

**Input**
\[ "SummaryRanges ",  "addNum ",  "getIntervals ",  "addNum ",  "getIntervals ",  "addNum ",  "getIntervals ",  "addNum ",  "getIntervals ",  "addNum ",  "getIntervals "\]
\[\[\], \[1\], \[\], \[3\], \[\], \[7\], \[\], \[2\], \[\], \[6\], \[\]\]
**Output**
\[null, null, \[\[1, 1\]\], null, \[\[1, 1\], \[3, 3\]\], null, \[\[1, 1\], \[3, 3\], \[7, 7\]\], null, \[\[1, 3\], \[7, 7\]\], null, \[\[1, 3\], \[6, 7\]\]\]

**Explanation**
SummaryRanges summaryRanges = new SummaryRanges();
summaryRanges.addNum(1);      // arr = \[1\]
summaryRanges.getIntervals(); // return \[\[1, 1\]\]
summaryRanges.addNum(3);      // arr = \[1, 3\]
summaryRanges.getIntervals(); // return \[\[1, 1\], \[3, 3\]\]
summaryRanges.addNum(7);      // arr = \[1, 3, 7\]
summaryRanges.getIntervals(); // return \[\[1, 1\], \[3, 3\], \[7, 7\]\]
summaryRanges.addNum(2);      // arr = \[1, 2, 3, 7\]
summaryRanges.getIntervals(); // return \[\[1, 3\], \[7, 7\]\]
summaryRanges.addNum(6);      // arr = \[1, 2, 3, 6, 7\]
summaryRanges.getIntervals(); // return \[\[1, 3\], \[6, 7\]\]

**Constraints:**

*   `0 <= value <= 104`
*   At most `3 * 104` calls will be made to `addNum` and `getIntervals`.
*   At most `102` calls will be made to `getIntervals`.

**Follow up:** What if there are lots of merges and the number of disjoint intervals is small compared to the size of the data stream?

"A steam locomotive is a locomotive that provides the force to move itself and other vehicles by means of the expansion of steam. It is fuelled by burning combustible material (usually coal, oil or, rarely, wood) to heat water in the locomotive's boiler to the point where it becomes gaseous and its volume increases 1,700 times. Functionally, it is a steam engine on wheels.

In most locomotives, the steam is admitted alternately to each end of its cylinders in which pistons are mechanically connected to the locomotive's main wheels. Fuel and water supplies are usually carried with the locomotive, either on the locomotive itself or in a tender coupled to it. Dangers and Best Practices

When attempting to rewrite history, always check the dangers of the particular command you’re using and follow these best practices for the commands we’ve covered:

Ideally, stick to using these commands only on branches that you’re working with by yourself.
Using the -f flag to force something should scare you, and you better have a really good reason for using it.
Don’t push after every single commit, changing published history should be avoided when possible.
Regarding the specific commands we’ve covered:
For git amend never amend commits that have been pushed to remote repositories.
For git rebase never rebase a repository that others may work off of.
For git reset never reset commits that have been pushed to remote repositories.
For git push --force only use it when appropriate, use it with caution, and preferably default to using git push --force-with-lease.

Deconstruction. Derrida
<extra_id_1>Assistant
Deconstruction is a mode of thought and analysis developed by the philosopher Jacques Derrida. It examines the underlying assumptions and power structures of a given set of ideas or discourse, and seeks to "deconstruct" these by exposing their inherent contradictions and inconsistencies. Derrida argued that all systems of thought are unstable and self-referential, and can never fully capture or express the complexity of reality. He also emphasized the importance of difference and otherness, embracing the inherent paradoxes and conflicts within all human experience.

Write all the sentences with the word "irritants" in the reference text. In two sentences, describe how bronchitis is diagnosed. Sort out the symptoms of bronchitis in alphabetical order.

Reference text:
What are the symptoms of bronchitis?
The most common symptoms of bronchitis are:

Runny, stuffy nose
Low-grade fever
Chest congestion
Wheezing or a whistling sound while breathing
A cough that may produce yellow or green mucus (sputum)
Feeling run-down or tired
How Is Bronchitis Diagnosed?
During the first few days of illness, bronchitis symptoms are similar to that of a common cold. Healthcare providers diagnose bronchitis by asking patients questions about symptoms and doing a physical examination. Though they rarely order additional tests, if you have a fever, your physician may order a chest X-ray to rule out pneumonia.

Preventing Bronchitis
Avoiding lung irritants, including smoking, is important for preventing bronchitis. To help protect your lungs, wear a mask over your mouth and nose when using lung irritants such as paint, paint remover or varnish. Wash your hands often, and receive a flu shot every year. Ask your doctor if you should get a pneumonia shot, especially if you're 65 or older.

How Is Bronchitis Treated?
Most cases of bronchitis go away on their own. The infection simply has to run its course over several weeks. Treatment options your doctor may suggest are:

Resting and getting plenty of fluids
Drinking lots of water, which helps loosen chest congestion
A cough suppressant and/or pain reliever
A humidifier or steam
Antibiotics are not effective for treating viral infections, but if your doctor suspects that you have a bacterial infection, they may prescribe one.

I just want to respond to the answer about Integral Yoga and about the Pope. I don't know why this yoga should be seen as something trivial. I rather have the feeling that Buddhism always has to be placed above everything else, even when information about other things is missing. This yoga is a mixture of dhyana, bhakti, and karma yoga — which is important when combined — no weakness, no moonshine. The tradition is several thousand years old, older than Buddhism. In essence it doesn't differ from Buddhism, it's just much simpler, freer, without technical manuals and instructions and all the various BDC apparatus. And another thing about the Pope: if he said that people in Africa shouldn't use condoms, he was speaking to married couples — he wasn't promoting premarital sex, so he wasn't spreading AIDS. And if anyone thinks Africa is overpopulated, that's a mistake: children are needed there more than here; many die, and for instance the Congo is larger than Europe with only 2.6 million people. The Pope did nothing without thought — before his statements he carefully studied the situation in each country with many people. And the 'comedy' around death? Does anyone here think that when the Dalai Lama dies, every Buddhist eye will remain dry — and that this is the 'ideal of an enlightened mind'? I think that if we love someone, we cry when they die, even if we know they continue. But I suppose here one only criticizes. Who can judge another's wisdom? The Pope's consciousness was and is all-pervading — of that I'm certain. So he was no fool. He just doesn't match Buddhist ideas of wisdom. P.S. Who said that BDC is the fastest and most direct method? Even my common sense tells me that's not possible... I just wanted to write: before the author issues a 'verdict,' it wouldn't hurt to pause and also use reason, and to realize that Truth never looks from just one side — let alone from the side of DC.

Radku, Radku — get your terminology a bit in order. Kalachakra is not a dual but a non-dual tantra (your answer to Mirek from December 6th). The body of light (Tib. ösel) is a Buddhist term and has a different meaning from the rainbow body (Tib. jalü). The rainbow body is a synonym for the perfect state of buddhahood — the fruit of the path of the tantras. The body of light is realized through the practices of trekcho and thogal, which belong to the highest practices of Dzogchen — at that point the practitioner dissolves their body into light after death. (Your answer to David from December 7th.) Once I asked you why lama Ole doesn't give samayas, and you answered that samayas are for very advanced practitioners and mean, for example, that you will never get angry. Such a samaya, as far as I know, does not exist — at least not among the 14 root samayas and 8 branch samayas. There are also 40 minor samayas. In any case, tantra never rejects disturbing emotions, so such a vow would be out of place. If anger can be transformed into wisdom, why renounce it? There is also an article on the 14 main samayas by Shamar Rinpoche — it's on his website too. Take care and keep writing poems.

Ole writes that an enlightened person is connected to all information and always knows the exact time. The Karmapa is of course a free play of mind and can do whatever he wants (though I don't understand why a top sprinter would ride in a wheelchair). He could somehow demonstrate his enlightenment so that students can also see the greatness and level of their teacher. Everyone should test their teacher, and if the teacher is enlightened, he also has — colloquially speaking — "mystical" abilities, and should therefore allow students to recognize that he truly has them. 2) How does the Karmapa manifest his enlightenment? What in his conduct is mystical — beyond wise speech and behavior toward those around him — or something that an ordinary person of high mental development doesn't also do? I've heard many stories, but nothing concrete that could be directly observed (like, say, those watches). Not that the Karmapa's enlightenment matters much to me. Buddhism is true, and the Karmapa's non-enlightenment wouldn't put me off it. But I care about every piece of the big puzzle, and the Karma Kagyu lineage is based precisely on the teacher... 3) What level of development does Ole have? Does he achieve enlightenment during every meditation? (By the way, he also wears a watch and checks the time.) 4) I went to Hungary over the weekend to receive a lung. A Diamond Mind meditation was practiced there. We were supposed to imagine Africa, madhouses, etc., as a black cloud that we breathe in and breathe out as clean air. I want to ask who this act actually helps: a) Me — in which case it subconsciously creates a false impression that I'm helping those people; b) Those people I'm imagining — in which case I don't understand how, if their conditions are their karma and unless they themselves work toward change, my meditation can't help them by the principle of causality anyway, and we're back to creating a false impression of helping. You don't need to be a psychologist to realize that most people doing this meditation subconsciously get the impression that they're helping people in need and don't need to help them in any other way. Meanwhile they're sitting on their backsides in the warmth of home. This question could be extended to meditations for the dead, etc. 5) Is meditation and what we feel (experience) in it only and precisely a reflection of one's overall current level of mental development? 6) Is enlightenment a merging with the principle of causality — not just understanding it and striving to act according to it, but literally fusing with this principle? 7) Even from the time before I encountered Buddhism, I've held a conviction that human consciousness (existence, being) is in fact just one. To put it to its logical conclusion: this question is being written by myself to myself (that is, to you), only at a different time and place and with different acquired information and starting conditions. This would also fit from the perspective of causality. If I do wrong to you, "later" I'll experience the consequences of my actions in my own skin. Time doesn't exist (plays no role) — perfect causality. There are few things I'm convinced of in this reality, but this is one of them. Even if I no longer live by it, I at least try to experience it more and more personally. Is this concept the view of a Buddhist, a crackpot, or some other faith or philosophy (which one)? Again, thank you for everything you do for all of us. In my life I've chosen several teachers. Currently they are Ole (through his books), but even more significantly you — you're more accessible, I can contact you more quickly, you've convinced me with your answers on everything, and you're probably not as busy as Ole. I believe you understand that I'm not trying to needle you, but you have to admit that with these unanswered questions I have a hard time on my Diamond Way. Thank you, Marian.

A smaller portion of those people then transforms it into experience, but even for them it was initially just faith — faith that Ole isn't talking nonsense and that he really is a genuine holder of the Dharma. Only a very small number of people see clearly right away. The vast majority believe first. The same applies during various group practices: when the lama is visualized as the embodiment of this or that, the first step for most people present is faith that it is so, and they gradually become convinced through lived experience and realization. I'd like to ask again after a long time about something that caught my attention. I'll say upfront that I'm not a Buddhist, but my brother is and we occasionally discuss various topics. Yesterday I looked at your website for the first time and happened to read the introduction — the key terms — and I was struck by this statement: "What is the significance of the teacher? The popular Western notion of achieving enlightenment alone cannot compare to the rapid success of complete practice with a teacher or in a group. Although achieving enlightenment alone sounds very appealing to the modern person who feels master of their own life, it presents too many pitfalls. Understanding the mind is far more treacherous than studying external phenomena, and enemies in the form of pride and displeasure always lurk, capable of derailing a given individual's development. The highest level of teaching cannot be properly understood or maintained without a teacher. If the communication that neutralizes pride, sentimentality and superficiality is absent, a person can become lonely or useless in everyday life. The lama uses methods to develop the potential of his students, enabling them to push through layers of habitual behavior. The lama's role is to make his students independent, compassionate and strong. At the highest level he allows his students to enter the fearless mirror-hall of his mind. Once they then discover that they share the same nature, there is nothing left to find out." I couldn't understand from what position you claim that something cannot compare to something else. My brother wasn't able to answer me, which is why I'm asking here. I agree that there are many pitfalls — such is life. I don't want to separate life from spiritual life, but how do you know that progress will be faster with a teacher or in a group? I don't want to analyze the very notion of progress here, which I also consider at least debatable — that's for a longer exchange of views. How do you know it's not possible to understand and maintain the final state without a teacher? Again I don't want to discuss the maintenance of a final state since I don't quite understand what that means, but what interests me is: where does your certainty come from that what you believe is good, and that what you believe should be achieved, is somehow better with a teacher? Who can claim this? And please don't say an enlightened person, because then that person couldn't view things in an enlightened way if they made such a claim — it would be asserting that something is better than something else, which is dualism, isn't it? Please understand, I don't want to argue, I'm just struck by the above. Who gave you this patent? I have nothing against Buddhism, it just — no offense, please don't take it personally — smells a bit like selling spirituality. You know, if it said that the meaning of a teacher is only to advise when asked, nothing could be objected to, but this invites debate. Maybe you'll object that your Buddhist experience is such, but what if other experiences are completely different? And wasn't the Buddha himself an example of the denial of the above? He didn't need a teacher — was he somehow exceptional? My view is that he was not. Don't you think that whatever path I choose, the only thing that matters is the strength of my sincerity? After all, the inner teacher — or whatever it is — is always present. Outer teachers can only point to a reality obscured by ignorance, but being is something a person experiences for themselves, in quotation marks. How can anyone claim that something is better than something else? Everything is as it is. Why single something out from something else when there's nothing to single it out from? And that sincerity can only be cultivated within myself. I'll add that I'm not a follower of any teaching. Thanks in advance again for the response. With respect, Petr Dvorak

Whoever is genuinely interested in Buddhism is primarily interested in the core of this more or less profound psychology — namely the so-called absorptions (jhanas/samadhis). And generally, the entire spiritual teaching is usually explained in such a way that it has neither head nor tail, and a beginner is left with a confused mess out of it. Almost everyone keeps talking to them about various types of yoga, concentration — whether on the spiritual heart, or on the Self, or on nothing. But all of these are vanities always overcome by our vitality, which — let's admit it — sometimes does with us whatever it wants. It determines whether we want something or not. Whether we give something up or not. But in the end this isn't a matter of rational deliberation. That's why it's important for a person to understand yoga not as concentration, but above all as a way of life. That's why we must begin with yogic pre-training. This is divided into YAMA and NIYAMA. The problem of a happy or unhappy life is a problem of feeling. And since from the standpoint of yoga this problem must be solved first, YAMA is prescribed as the first step. YAMA means discipline of feeling. Through it, happiness is literally "manufactured." An angry, biased and unpleasant person would like to throw all of this behind them and simply sit down in some yogic posture and concentrate until they become happy. But it is not possible to arrive at feelings of happiness through concentration alone, nor is it possible to achieve discernment through moral discipline alone, so that consciousness can free itself from the last dregs of ignorance. Everything has its time and sequence. So one needs to observe those "unpleasant" moral commandments. But how? Whenever a person tries to put them into practice, they either forget about them, or despite adhering to them they get agitated, are resentful, greedy, biased, or gossip. So if I am to observe the commandments of morality I must do it ACCOMPANIED by a happy mood, a peaceful mind, trust and optimism. The main tool for this is our WILL, by which we deliberately — and against all circumstances — maintain joy, above all JOY WITHOUT CAUSE (that is, independent of surroundings and people). And the more we hold to this joy, the more we will smooth out potential states of the opposite mood. And our happiness will be COMPLETE. The second step is NIYAMA. It concerns bodily and mental hygiene. A person should attend to their appearance, be attentive in dealings with people so as not to appear eccentric. Show restraint in judgments, not react to any behavior or event spontaneously. And occupy the mind by reading spiritual literature and seeking out company engaged in noble deeds and teachings. Enlightenment and perfect self-knowledge bring a person to the level of a sage, whereas yogic pre-training brings them to the level of an ABSOLUTELY HAPPY person — that is, at the end of moral transubstantiation. What I want to say is that practicing meditation without PREPARATION makes no sense. Every beginner should be aware of that. Otherwise they will be disappointed.

But since I started sempa (Skt.: sampa — wish/aspiration practices), problems began to appear. At first I started having quite strong depressive episodes, which wasn't usual for me. I told myself something was simply being purified and slowed down for a while. But then I started experiencing something at night when falling asleep: Ole would appear above my bed and beam silver light from his forehead into mine. At first I was confused by this, but after some time I came to terms with it and even found joy in it. Later he started appearing much more frequently and it disturbed me in ordinary communication with people — whatever I or anyone around me did, he commented from the perspective of the karmic consequences of such an action. Then Mahakala took his place — I had the feeling he was constantly watching me, pursuing me, and I was running from him, hiding. In connection with this I unfortunately hurt a family member and was taken to Bohnice (a psychiatric hospital in Prague). A week ago I was released from the closed ward — I feel completely fine and can look at what happened with some detachment. However, I still have to take antipsychotics — the doctors said if I stopped, the illness might return. I'd like to ask whether I can now carefully start meditating again. I feel fine, but I'm not certain. On the other hand — now that I'm not meditating — I feel terribly useless. I know this is probably silly, but I can't get rid of the feeling. I'd also like to know if you have any explanation for what happened. The head doctor told me they'd had another Buddhist there half a year ago — a guy who had the feeling that the Karmapa was in his head instead of his brain and that he was thinking and acting on the Karmapa's behalf. I wanted to speak with that guy but the doctor refused to give me his contact. It occurred to me whether you might have any experience with a similar case. Perhaps I was doing the meditations somehow "incorrectly" — that's mainly why I wanted to talk to that guy, to see if we could find some common error. I simply don't know and it keeps gnawing at my mind. At least I have a partner with whom I can openly talk about everything. That helps a lot. I can't imagine getting through this with someone (a non-Buddhist) who doesn't understand how important practice is to me. Thank you so very much for a response, and may things go well for you! Jana.

For online sources, use the following format:

Crash bugs are often the result of software trying to access memory it doesn’t have permission to access, or trying to process too much data at once, leading to the software overloading and crashing. In the United States, it is widely read in high schools and middle schools. To Kill a Mockingbird has become a classic of modern American literature, winning the Pulitzer Prize. The plot and characters are loosely based on Lee's observations of her family, her neighbors and an event that occurred near her hometown of Monroeville, Alabama, in 1936, when she was ten.

Despite dealing with the serious issues of rape and racial inequality, the novel is renowned for its warmth and humor. Atticus Finch, the narrator's father, has served as a moral hero for many readers and as a model of integrity for lawyers. The historian Joseph Crespino explains, "In the twentieth century, To Kill a Mockingbird is probably the most widely read book dealing with race in America, and its main character, Atticus Finch, the most enduring fictional image of racial heroism."[1] As a Southern Gothic novel and Bildungsroman, the primary themes of To Kill a Mockingbird involve racial injustice and the destruction of innocence. Scholars have noted that Lee also addresses issues of class, courage, compassion, and gender roles in the Deep South. The book is widely taught in schools in the United States with lessons that emphasize tolerance and decry prejudice.[2] Despite its themes, To Kill a Mockingbird has been subject to campaigns for removal from public classrooms, often challenged for its use of racial epithets. In 2006, British librarians ranked the book ahead of the Bible as one "every adult should read before they die".[3]

I was a bit surprised by your approach to meat as food. It's clear that humans have been eating meat for thousands of years, and after all, every predatory animal must kill in order to survive, or simply to live in good accordance with its own body. What puzzles me is why eating 'anonymous' meat — slaughtered by some butcher on a production line — is recommended here. Surely by buying such meat I send the signal that more animals should be slaughtered. Second: what about the poor butcher? If he really is the one who 'absorbs' all the karma, that seems deeply unfair to him. Let me put it this way: I don't want someone to be harmed so that I can eat in peace. In the end I think a 'clean death' is far less karmically negative than the conditions in which unfortunate chickens live in modern chicken farms — what Stanislaw Lem called chicken Auschwitzes. In short, it seems somewhat hypocritical to me — I don't actually change reality by hiding in the crowd or by putting someone else out front who doesn't even properly know they've been put there. That said, I very much enjoy this column — otherwise I wouldn't be writing to it. So to end on a positive note: I wish you much strength!

Coral reefs are the most diverse of all marine ecosystems. They teem with life, with perhaps one-quarter of all ocean species depending on reefs for food and shelter. This is a remarkable statistic when you consider that reefs cover just a tiny fraction (less than one percent) of the earth’s surface and less than two percent of the ocean bottom. Because they are so diverse, coral reefs are often called the rainforests of the sea.

Coral reefs are also very important to people. The value of coral reefs has been estimated at 30 billion U.S. dollars and perhaps as much as 172 billion U.S. dollars each year, providing food, protection of shorelines, jobs based on tourism, and even medicines.

Unfortunately, people also pose the greatest threat to coral reefs. Overfishing and destructive fishing, pollution, warming, changing ocean chemistry, and invasive species are all taking a huge toll. In some places, reefs have been entirely destroyed, and in many places reefs today are a pale shadow of what they once were.

A bear put spread involves buying a put option on a stock and selling a put option on the same stock, with a lower strike price. You, a Buddhist teacher, write that not eating meat is confused and less significant than other forms of active compassion? If you find it more 'active' to simply 'think' while consuming meat — in the way you describe, that you're thereby helping the animal toward a better rebirth — that strikes me as a very convenient belief. And you call the active effort to reduce demand for meat 'confusion.' Maybe you yourself are confused in this regard and haven't yet recognized the real reason why you eat meat and defend it. You say you're beyond concepts, so I suppose there's no point asking whether it seems right to you. And the claim that you're not having animals killed for yourself is a mistake — a large market, in my view, will not absolve you of the fact that you're creating demand for that meat. Arguments like 'there is a bond between the butcher and the pig that must be resolved' — that's, to my mind, another convenient alibi, one that denies free will and choice. Isn't the power of the mind a significant part of Buddhist philosophy? I know people who don't eat meat because they experience genuine, active compassion for those animals. I personally try not to eat it for rational reasons — it's unnecessary. Whatever the case may be — even if people who don't eat meat want to feel superior to others — no argument can refute the fundamental point: that because of them, those animals are not being bred and made to suffer. So to my question: do you actually eat meat because you genuinely believe you're helping the animal? And if so, how have you verified that you are?  Also one more thing — do you think your lineage's goal of helping people is served by giving people arguments that allow them to eat a nice meal with a clear conscience?

Other books include Love Poems & Others, The Basic Colours, Priority, Steps, Doing the Same in English, A Tour of the Lattice, Several Dances A Line of Tiny Zeros in the Fabric.

Maurice Scully born was in Dublin in 1952 spent his childhood between Clare, the Ring Gaeltacht, and Dublin. He attended Trinity College in Dublin.

Many years living in Italy, Greece, Africa and the west of Ireland, Scully settled with his wife and four children in Dublin, he taught for a times at Dublin City University.

Prof. Kevin Rafter, Chair of the Arts Council, said: "Deeply saddened Arts Council to hear of passing of renowned poet Maurice Scully. His writing display tremendous sensitive and empathy, earn him loyal readers across the world. His death is a great loss to Irish literature."

Maureen Kennelly, Director of the Arts Council, commented: "Maurice Scully were an esteemed poet and member of Aosdána. He made a wide and rich contribution to writing over his long careers. How does Karmapa Thila Dorje experience, as a Buddha, the fact that every existing being is under his protection — as Christ might? There are countless numbers of people, as well as incorporeal human souls, worlds of various dimensions, galaxies and the entire universe. The sun is not alone — there are entire galaxies. What is Buddha within all this existence? I imagine Buddha as myself — Buddha has the capacity to be everywhere and to be everything. Everyone is Buddha. But there are servants of Buddha, and Karmapa is one — he serves the Buddha by directing the attention of small Buddhas back to themselves, not to selfishness, but to themselves as Buddhas. The only help lies in unification. In an identification that already exists. That would mean that Karmapa and Buddha are me — but he sees more clearly. There's no problem here like the one you have in a trolleybus or in an apartment block, where everyone is cramped and physically squashed together. Buddha is a co-experiencer, but has intentionally assumed a kind of individual monastic identity in order to encourage himself within us. What irritates me is everything a person has to go through before growing into Buddhahood. Karmapa is probably my own self — but he plays the role of a teacher, wanting to serve me, to serve me as Buddha. But what a difficult service it must be, when I don't even know I am the Buddha he serves. How hard it must be for him to convince me that I am the Buddha he is serving. A great problem across eons of time. No wonder that Christ sweated blood. That is only a small image of the eternal blood and suffering of the Buddha, who simply wishes to lift other selves just a little into his own liberation. And then there's the body and the name — obstacles all the way.

Setting aside a number of other things, here is one that stands out. A large part of Buddhist teaching and its truths stands or falls on the fact of reincarnation and some kind of higher good that ensures a better next incarnation for those who behave in a certain way. And unlike other things that can at least be defended by logic, there is no — and probably never has been any — tangible proof of this. The entire body of knowledge and understanding (with a few interpretive exceptions) tends toward the conclusion that this is simply not the case. In other words: the more we know, the fewer possibilities there are to defend it, and that is deeply troubling. Death then ends everything connected with a given being, and the meaning of nirvana — and of all Buddhist striving — falls apart. What if there is no cycle in connection with the 'soul'? What if all suffering ends at death? Then the idea of karma — and essentially all similar ideas — is hardly defensible. This entire magnificent system of thought rests on a foundation that one simply must take on faith. I consider Buddhism the religion closest to humanity. Yet the Four Noble Truths may very well be only four half-truths. Honza
